image.title: Radio Sweden - Swedish news in English

channel.itunes:summary: Radio Swedens weekday programming is a window on the diverse perspectives and issues in Sweden today. Our daily editions offer a smorgasbord of news and current affairs, science and technology, lifestyle, and culture.
channel.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 19th August 2014
item.description: Relief for several families as Russian authorities finally allow their adoptive children to join them in Sweden....The Christian Democrat leader praises Swedes` support for openness and democracy - after getting pied by "the Fag Army"....And we hear from the director behind a Swedish blockbuster. Music: Terribly Dark by Frida Hyvönen. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Frank Radosevich.
item.itunes:summary: Relief for several families as Russian authorities finally allow their adoptive children to join them in Sweden....The Christian Democrat leader praises Swedes` support for openness and democracy - after getting pied by "the Fag Army"....And we hear from the director behind a Swedish blockbuster. Music: Terribly Dark by Frida Hyvönen. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Frank Radosevich.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 18th August 2014
item.description: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange says he will soon be leaving the Ecuadorian embassy in London. Two Swedish journalists revealed the Saudi weapon`s scandal. Now the book is released. We talk to one of the authors. Today sees the first instalment of our series of party leader interviews. We talk to the Left Party`s Jonas Sjöstedt. Presenter: Ulla Engberg
item.itunes:summary: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange says he will soon be leaving the Ecuadorian embassy in London. Two Swedish journalists revealed the Saudi weapon`s scandal. Now the book is released. We talk to one of the authors. Today sees the first instalment of our series of party leader interviews. We talk to the Left Party`s Jonas Sjöstedt. Presenter: Ulla Engberg
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 15th August 2014
item.description: Rising number of asylum seekers from Ukraine. How much to trust online quizzes intended to help you decide which party to vote for. This week marks 200 years of unbroken peace in Sweden, which is a record. We delve into what this means for the country. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou
item.itunes:summary: Rising number of asylum seekers from Ukraine. How much to trust online quizzes intended to help you decide which party to vote for. This week marks 200 years of unbroken peace in Sweden, which is a record. We delve into what this means for the country. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 14 August 2014
item.description: A frontline MP from the Liberal Party wants Sweden to give military support to help the Kurds in northern Iraq. Two weeks to the day since the outbreak of Sweden`s biggest forest fire in modern times we hear from some of those evacuees who`ve returned home.
item.itunes:summary: A frontline MP from the Liberal Party wants Sweden to give military support to help the Kurds in northern Iraq. Two weeks to the day since the outbreak of Sweden`s biggest forest fire in modern times we hear from some of those evacuees who`ve returned home.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 13 August 2014
item.description: The Listeria outbreak in Sweden with no end in sight. Party political posters are starting to appear on the streets of Sweden as the general election draws near but do the old methods of campaigning still hold today? He missed out on the recent World Cup as a player but Zlatan Ibrahimovic has dug into his pockets to make sure one of Sweden`s unsung national teams has made it to Brazil.
item.itunes:summary: The Listeria outbreak in Sweden with no end in sight. Party political posters are starting to appear on the streets of Sweden as the general election draws near but do the old methods of campaigning still hold today? He missed out on the recent World Cup as a player but Zlatan Ibrahimovic has dug into his pockets to make sure one of Sweden`s unsung national teams has made it to Brazil.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 11th August 2014
item.description: We look at whether taking the word "race" away from Swedish laws can help fight racism. We hear why there are so few people over the age of 65 in the Swedish Riksdag. And we find out more about two big culture festivals hitting the streets of Stockholm tomorrow. Producer/Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Song: "Där palmerna bor" by Medina.
item.itunes:summary: We look at whether taking the word "race" away from Swedish laws can help fight racism. We hear why there are so few people over the age of 65 in the Swedish Riksdag. And we find out more about two big culture festivals hitting the streets of Stockholm tomorrow. Producer/Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Song: "Där palmerna bor" by Medina.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 8th August 2014
item.description: Russia strikes back with sanctions of its own with a one-year ban on Western food imports. We hear how Sweden may be hurt by the measures. And later we get a taste of what today`s host of the Sommar radio show has in store. Continuing with our election coverage, we take a look back at the Parliament`s youngest party: the Sweden Democrats. And our Friday guest talks about how he went from being a struggling blacksmith to forging swords for Hollywood stars. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Paris" by Little Dragon.
item.itunes:summary: Russia strikes back with sanctions of its own with a one-year ban on Western food imports. We hear how Sweden may be hurt by the measures. And later we get a taste of what today`s host of the Sommar radio show has in store. Song: "Paris" by Little Dragon.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 7th August 2014
item.description: It`s been burning for more than a week but information about Sweden massive wildfire isn`t reaching everyone. Sweden`s government is putting forth 2 million kronor to help protect the nation`s Jewish communities. And we speak to a Swedish scientist who`s part of a project that saw a space probe rendezvous with a comet. Producer: George Wood. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: “Sången de spelar när filmen är slut” by Peter LeMarc.
item.itunes:summary: It`s been burning for more than a week but information about Sweden massive wildfire isn`t reaching everyone. Sweden`s government is putting forth 2 million kronor to help protect the nation`s Jewish communities. And we speak to a Swedish scientist who`s part of a project that saw a space probe rendezvous with a comet. Producer: George Wood. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: “Sången de spelar när filmen är slut” by Peter LeMarc.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 6th August 2014
item.description: As central Sweden continues to fight a massive forest fire, one woman is trying to help people through Facebook. We hear about the history and platform of Sweden`s Center Party and learn more about a theater festival with a political twist in Kärrtorp. Finally, we saddle up with a group of medieval knights doing battle for charity. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "No Coke" by Dr. Alban.
item.itunes:summary: As central Sweden continues to fight a massive forest fire, one woman is trying to help people through Facebook. We hear about the history and platform of Sweden`s Center Party and learn more about a theater festival with a political twist in Kärrtorp. Finally, we saddle up with a group of medieval knights doing battle for charity. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "No Coke" by Dr. Alban.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 5th August 2014
item.description: A massive forest fire in central Sweden continues to spread prompting the evacuation of hundreds.Authorities are warning Swedes that the so-called "barbie" drug is not to be played with. We hear from an aquarium in western Sweden that released some sharks into the water. But, not to worry, they`re no threat to humans. And things get medieval this week on Sweden`s Baltic island of Gotland. Stay tuned to find out why. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Dansen före döden" by Thomas Stenström.

We hear from an aquarium in western Sweden that released some sharks into the water. But, not to worry, they`re no threat to humans. item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 4th August 2014
item.description: Researchers are setting sailing this week across the Baltic to study pollution caused by plastics. Sweden joins other countries in the call for a worldwide ban on female genital mutilation. Hundreds of Swedes have found themselves stuck in Somalia after their travel company folded last week - we hear from one for the stranded passengers. And we visit a group in southern Sweden who were busy this weekend surviving the bird flu apocalypse. Not to worry - it was just in their imagination. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "These Walls Don`t Lie" by Promoe.

Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "These Walls Don`t Lie" by Promoe.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 31st July 2014
item.description: The polls open today for Swedes living overseas. And one group wants to make sure they cast their vote. Foreign Minister Carl Bildt puts forth his solution for ending the fighting in Gaza. Experts look at ways to make Sweden`s streets safer for cyclists. And is it true that Sweden`s a dark, frozen wasteland? Producer: Kris Boswell. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "I Samma Bil" by Bo Kaspers Okester.

Foreign Minister Carl Bildt puts forth his solution for ending the fighting in Gaza. Experts look at ways to make Sweden`s streets safer for cyclists. And is it true that Sweden`s a dark, frozen wasteland? Producer: Kris Boswell. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "I Samma Bil" by Bo Kaspers Okester.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 30th of July 2014
item.description: What`s it like being queer in Sweden`s indigenous community? Archeologists uncover 20 missing 300-year-old Swedish battle ships. Business is booming for the country`s beekeepers. And are the Swedes really as shy and cold as the stereotype would have it? Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Frank Radosevich. Music: I Got You by Ola Salo and Kleerup.

item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 29th of July 2014
item.description: Investments by Swedish fund companies could be in danger because of possible EU sanctions against Russia. Swedes throw tonnes of edible food in the garbage - we find out how to reduce food waste. We catch up with football coach Pia Sundhage ahead of the weekend game against England. And our summer series explores the Swedish school system. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Frank Radosevich. Music: Precis som jag by Daniel Adams-Ray.

item.title: 28th of July 2014
item.description: Evictions of homeless EU migrants are increasing in number. Social democrat leader Stefan Löfven continues to make headlines over Gaza conflict. Calls to renew a subsidy plan for environmentally friendly cars. And gene therapy offers new treatments for challenging diseases. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Frank Radosevich. Music: Annie Leibovitz by Timbuktu.

item.title: 25th of July 2014
item.description: Swedes under fire in Gaza and Israel describe their experiences. A new intiative wants men to talk about rape. Are topless women being discriminated against? More and more Swedes save their vacation days for the winter. And our summer series takes a look at Sweden`s reputation as one of the world`s least corrupt countries. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Kris Boswell. Music: As Scared As You by Slow Fox and Frida Selander.

item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 24th of July 2014
item.description: Swedish authorities are unprepared to deal with rising organized crime. Food safety is on the agenda, as the month known by the Swedes as the rotting month begins. Young Swedes are flocking to the Stockholm opera houses. And we find out if Swedes are really as afraid of conflict as the stereotypes would have it. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Kris Boswell. Music: Inna City Mamma by Neneh Cherry.

Music: Inna City Mamma by Neneh Cherry.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 23rd of July 2014
item.description: Flights between Sweden and Israel`s main city are cancelled over safety fears. Girls and boys can - and should - play sports together, for society`s sake, one expert says. A new law sparks a building boom for tiny houses. And, are Swedes really as ok with nudity as the world seems to think? Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Music: Let it Heal by Syket.
item.itunes:summary: Flights between Sweden and Israel`s main city are cancelled over safety fears. Girls and boys can - and should - play sports together, for society`s sake, one expert says. item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 22th of July 2014
item.description: Three years after the terrorist attacks in Norway, one survivor thinks we are failing to stop xenophobic attitudes. An opera about a British feminist chasing a silver ship through Scandinavia premieres this summer. Despite a housing shortage, hundreds of building projects are delayed. And we find out if being Swedish mean learning how to fall in line, in part 12 of our summer series. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Music: Lasse Stefanz with Sara Solsken.
item.itunes:summary: Three years after the terrorist attacks in Norway, one survivor thinks we are failing to stop xenophobic attitudes. An opera about a British feminist chasing a silver ship through Scandinavia premieres this summer. Despite a housing shortage, hundreds of building projects are delayed. And we find out if being Swedish mean learning how to fall in line, in part 12 of our summer series. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Music: Lasse Stefanz with Sara Solsken.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 21st of July 2014
item.description: Longer waiting times for Syrian refugees wanting to reunite with family in Sweden. A new authority could help Sweden prevent suicides. Swedes love excersing, but is the country really all that healthy? And 3D printers can solve medical problems. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Music: Fever Ray with When I Grow Up.

Music: Fever Ray with When I Grow Up.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 18th July 2014
item.description: What exactly happened to the Malaysian airliner over Ukraine? Sweden`s Foreign Minister thinks he knows. We look at the health risks posed by a tiny bloodsucker, common in the Swedish countryside during the summer. And then we find out whether this country really is as green and environmentally friendly as some think it is.
item.itunes:summary: What exactly happened to the Malaysian airliner over Ukraine? Sweden`s Foreign Minister thinks he knows. We look at the health risks posed by a tiny bloodsucker, common in the Swedish countryside during the summer. And then we find out whether this country really is as green and environmentally friendly as some think it is.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 17th July 2014
item.description: A Stockholm court has upheld its detention order on WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange. We get the reaction from his defence lawyer. Russia faces stricter sanctions - Swedish PM Fredrik Reinfeldt outlines his position in an interview with Swedish Radio. And do Swedes like paying taxes? We find out in the latest episode of our series on Swedish myths and stereotypes. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Music: Beautiful World by Jasmine Kara.

item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 16th July 2014
item.description: A Stockholm court hears Julian Assange`s bid to scrap his arrest warrant - we have the latest. We meet a woman who`s risked her life helping those who risk theirs to make it to Sweden. And are Swedes fashionistas or just frumpy? Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Stora Trygga Vargen" by Maskinen.
item.itunes:summary: A Stockholm court hears Julian Assange`s bid to scrap his arrest warrant - we have the latest. item.title: 15th July 2014
item.description: The European Parliament elected Jean-Claude Juncker as EU Commission President today. We heard from two of Sweden`s MEPs right after they cast their voted. A new study finds the carbon footprint from tourism is growing. The Bard of Avon comes to Stockholm this summer. And in our mythbusting series we meditate on whether Sweden really is a nordic nation of non-believers? Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Sing Hallelujah" by Dr. Alban.

item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 14th July 2014
item.description: Sweden`s Foreign Ministry is urging its citizens to leave the Gaza Strip as the fighting there continues. Foreigners heading to Sweden to pick berry this year could be left with a sour taste in their mouths. And is Sweden a shrine to socialism? Find out as we continue with a Swedish mythbusting series. And after the World Cup, thousands of teenagers are now swarming the streets of Gothenburg for a tournament of their own. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Rum i Göteborg" by Jonas Lundqvist.

item.title: 11th of July 2014
item.description: There`s outcry in Sweden over the air war going on in the Gaza Strip. How do you get people excited about a 400-year-old boat that sank before it even made it out of the harbour? And in part five of our summer series, we`ll find out if polar bears could ever walk the streets of Sweden. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Music: "I should`ve walked you home" by Agnetha Fältskog & Gary Barlow.

item.title: 10th of June 2014
item.description: The Swedish man who saved thousands of Jews from the Holocaust gets honored in the US. Young cancer patients suffer the effect of hospital staff shortages. More details about why internet alcohol sales may be threatening the Swedish alcohol monopoly. And part four in our summer series takes a look at Swedish gender equality. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Music: Sutka Flamenco by Svarta Safirer.

item.title: 9th of June 2014
item.description: Denmark wants homeless foreign beggars to go to Sweden instead. Swedish mental health care needs to step up its game, according to an international report. Football players from Darfur who went missing after a tournament are now seeking asylum in Sweden. And we uncover the naked truth about the so-called Swedish sin. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Music: Shu Katt by Linda Pira & Dani M.

item.title: 8th July 2014
item.description: Is the new Swedish chairmanship of an EU committee the result of a political coup? Video games are giving boys a leg up in English class. The government finds that measuring quality of life for the nation is easier said than done. And part two summer series takes a closer look at stereotypes surrounding Swedes and alcohol. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Music: Kär & Galen by Cleo & Kristin Amparo & Broke N Tipsy.

item.title: 7th July 2014
item.description: A controversial site publishing public records could pose a problem for personal privacy. Catch up on the speeches by the Liberal and Centre party leaders in Almedalen last week. Find out if there`s any basis to the myth of swedes being all blond and blue-eyed - and how the Swedish forestry industry is affecting biological diversity. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Music: Standing Strong by Sarah Dawn Finer.

item.title: 4th July 2014
item.description: Listen to our final broadcast from Almedalen week in Gotland. Today`s debate features free schools. Enjoy!

item.title: 3rd July 2014
item.description: Radio Sweden continues its coverage of Almedalen with Day Four of our special outside broadcast`s in Visby, Gotland. Today we`re discussing feminism and meeting Sweden`s secret police. Presenter:Dave Russell. Producer:Kris Boswell.

item.title: 1st July 2014
item.description: Day two of Radio Sweden`s broadcast from Almedalen week in Visby, Gotland. Join us for foreign politics chat, comedian Özz Nujen joins us and our reporter finds out if politics and booze do really mix. Presenter Dave Russell, Producer Kris Boswell and reporter Nathalie Rothschild.

Presenter Dave Russell, Producer Kris Boswell and reporter Nathalie Rothschild.

item.title: 30th June 2014
item.description: Radio Sweden broadcasts live from Almedalen in Visby, Gotland. Join Dave Russell and Kris Boswell and a mixture of guests for a half hour of politics and entertainment from the biggest political event ahead of the election.
item.itunes:summary: Radio Sweden broadcasts live from Almedalen in Visby, Gotland. Join Dave Russell and Kris Boswell and a mixture of guests for a half hour of politics and entertainment from the biggest political event ahead of the election.

item.title: 27 June 2014
item.description: We hear what Sweden`s doing as head of a UN project to find places for Syrian refugees. Our reporter delves deeper into what life is like for Sweden`s teachers. A hockey team is to play in rainbow colours, to show their support for gay rights. And we talk vikings, with an archaeologist who`s researching a rounder view of the notorious medieval raiders. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Brett Ascarelli.
item.itunes:summary: We hear what Sweden`s doing as head of a UN project to find places for Syrian refugees. Our reporter delves deeper into what life is like for Sweden`s teachers. A hockey team is to play in rainbow colours, to show their support for gay rights. And we talk vikings, with an archaeologist who`s researching a rounder view of the notorious medieval raiders. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Brett Ascarelli.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 26th June 2014
item.description: Sweden is now saying yes to the nomination of Jean-Claude Juncker as EU Commission President, despite the the UK`s loud campaign to block it. Will Reinfeldt and Cameron be able to patch things up? The Swedish government will appoint a national coordinator to help combat violent extremism. Tourism is on the rise in Sweden. Find out who`s coming and how much they`re spending. And we head to a center helping refugees in Sweden who have been the victims of torture. Producer: Kris Boswell. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Sunshine" by Teddybears.

And we look at a growing environmental problem at the bottom of the sea. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Kris Boswell. Music: Händerna mot himlen by Petra Marklund.

One Thailand expert we`ve spoken to says yes. Presenter: Kris Boswell. Producer: Frank Radosevich.

And we speak to the organiser of an existential film festival. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Kris Boswell. Music: I Don`t Care by Icona Pop.

item.title: 8th April 2014
item.description: Archaeologists uncover pieces of Stockholm`s history in the heart of the capital. Coast guard boats in southern Sweden cut speeds to save money. The EU`s top court overturns a law on keeping private data and we find out what this means for Sweden. And just how fast is your broadband? Maybe not as fast as think. Producer: Kris Boswell. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Music: "Huvudet i sanden" by Familjen.

Presenter: Ulla Engberg Music: First Aid Kit "My Silver Lining"

item.description: Calls for tougher measures against hooligans after a man dies as a result of football-related violence in Helsingborg. item.title: 28th March 2014
item.description: A court sends a Malaysian couple to prison for beating their children in Sweden. Music composers score new work in Sweden`s video game industry. item.title: 27 March 2014
item.description: Former industry minister Maud Olofsson will not appear before a parliamentary committee to answer questions about a disasterous purchase by the state-owned power company. A European politician says she has a solution to the deadlock over Sweden`s sex case against Julian Assange. A disarmament campaigner says nowadays, when she goes on the TV to argue for peace, people call her a traitor. And we hear the latest stamps from Sweden`s postal delivery service are selling like hot cakes, they feature Zlatan Ibrahimovic.

item.title: Radio Sweden 26 March 2014
item.description: A rights watchdog delivers harsh criticism about mental health care for young people; we gauge the economic impact of the crisis in Crimea on the Swedish economy; and, not for the faint-hearted, we bring you news of a monster rat under a kitchen sink. We also speak to Barbaro Lindgren, winner of this year`s Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award for children`s literature. And we have all the latest news and weather.

item.title: 25th March 2014
item.description: Hello and welcome to Radio Sweden. We`re live from Broadcasting House in Stockholm, with thirty minutes of news and comment from this Nordic nation. In today`s programme: Reaction to a report that details abuse and discrimination suffered by Sweden`s Roma community. And, scoring a goal for global understanding? A World Cup for stateless nations. Also, the winner of this year`s Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award for children`s literature is announced. We also have a round-up of the day`s top stories and the latest weather. Music: José Gonzalez, Stay Alive.

item.title: 24 March 2014
item.description: Sweden`s Education Minister wants to introduce marking for the nations fourth graders fails to impress. Thousands of migrating cranes make a record early appearance and hundreds of Stockholmers turn up for an exhibition said to be from the street artist Banksy, but was it all a hoax?

item.title: 20th March 2014
item.description: One woman`s video challenging body ideals goes viral on social media. Kids are getting scraps for breakfast at Swedish daycare centres. With six months until the election, how is Sweden doing? Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: Dave Russell. Music: La Belle Epoque by Kent.

item.title: 19th March 2014
item.description: A report says neo-Nazi activity in Sweden is on the rise. Then we hear how the mysterious but also famous street artist Banksy may come to Stockholm. But how will the authorities, with their zero tolerance on grafitti, respond? And the man once thought to be Sweden`s worst serial killer is now walking free. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Dave Russell.

item.title: 18th March 2014
item.description: A new partner takes the field at the financially troubled Friends Arena. Sweden`s dairy farmers celebrate their past while looking toward an uncertain future. Tough economic times are forcing more people out on the streets. And a landmark discovery in outer space could tell us more about the birth of the universe. Producer: Dave Russell. Presenter: Frank Radosevich.

item.description: Crimea declares it wants to join Russia, but what does it mean? And could ethanol pumps at petrol stations be about to dry up?

item.description: The standard of care available to troubled kids varies depending on where in the country you live, according to the children`s helpline BRIS. Articles featuring pictures of female politicians in cocktail dresses have upset some here, but the magazine editor defends the articles some are calling old-fashioned. And hear the story of the Nashville street musician making it big in Sweden.

item.title: 13th March 2014
item.description: Protesters face off against police clearing out a camp of Romanian migrants in a northern suburb of Stockholm. We hear how Sweden is falling it behind when it comes to using computers in the classroom. A new exhibit tells the lives of kings and queens: both real and imaginary. And a newly crowned baker tells us what it takes to make the perfect pastry. Producer: Markus Landén. Presenter: Frank Radosevich.

item.title: 12th March 2014
item.description: We hear listeners and colleagues share their memories of Swedish Radio correspondent Nils Horner who was killed in Afghanistan yesterday. There`s a call for doctors to be less lenient on elderly patients not fit to drive. A former Swedish colony in the Caribbean may seek compensation. And, it`s the hallmark of fine dining quality, find out if Sweden`s been awarded its first three starred Michelin restaurant. Producer: Dave Russell. Presenter: Markus Landén.

item.title: 11th March 2014
item.description: Today Swedish Radio correspondent Nils Horner was shot and killed this morning on a street in Afghanistan`s capital, Kabul. We hear from the head of Swedish Radio, from the person in charge of reporters` safety, and we also hear Nils himself, talking to us a couple of years ago, about the risks of the job. Then we`ll hear about the government`s latest proposal - a cash boost for the early school years that the opposition says is rather close to their own plans, and we also hear about changes in the way people work in Sweden, that some say means more stress. Producer: Markus Landén. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou

item.title: 10 March 2014
item.description: Another wave of demonstrations against nazism after a late night fight involving members of a neo-nazi party. Cancer treatment is getting too expensive - according to leading oncologists. Will a 50,000 bonus attract teachers to special needs education? One gold and one bronze for the Swedish team in the paralympics today. And Sweden`s entry into the Eurovisuion song contest has finally been selected. Music: Sanna Nielsen "Undo" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: 6th March 2014
item.description: Sweden`s Foreign Minister Carl Bildt is in Ukraine today discussing the deeping crisis there. We see what his visit means for Ukraine`s Crimean peninsula and Sweden. And a spoonful of sugar won`t help this medicine go down: new guidelines from the WHO say everyone should be eating less sugar. Finally, we analyze a new television series that has a psycho-therapist interviewing Sweden`s top politicians. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Producer: Kris Boswell.

item.description: Sweden freezes Uganda aid due to anti-gay law/Tempo documentary film festival/And how dirty dishes could be a thing of the past. Presenter Dave Russell/Producer Kris Boswell.

item.title: 3 March 2014
item.description: Russia`s intervention in the Ukraine has sparked a renewed debate about Sweden`s defence. The EU parliament approves a directive to try to stop young people from smoking - but will it be enough? The government has raised tax on alcohol, so why are the prize on some bottles of wine lower this week compared to last? Shop owners who don`t offer access for the disabled may soon face criminal charges. Young Swedes are no longer lazing around in front of the tv as they move to watch their favourite programmes online instead. Presenter: Ulla Engberg Music: Panetoz "Efter Solsken"

item.title: 28th February 2014
item.description: In today`s programme we hear how Sweden can be surprisingly influential in solving the crisis in Ukraine. The Swedish computer game Minecraft is going to be adapted for the silver screen. And we hear about a study that may get older men`s biological clocks ticking. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Presenter: Markus Landén

item.description: A commission looks into order in Swedish classrooms. Defence exports from Sweden shot up last year to nearly 12 billion krona. And warm weather threatens the Vasaloppet, the nation`s oldest cross-country ski race. Producer: Loukas Christadoulou. Presenter: Frank Radosevich.

item.description: Swedish reaction to new anti-gay legislation in Uganda, could development assistance to the African nation be questioned? And then how household rubbish from the UK and Ireland is heating houses and creating hot water in Sweden.

item.title: 21 February 2014
item.description: We hear from a Swedish politician in Kiev on a day when Ukraine protest leaders sign deal with President. One year on from the horse meat scandal has anything changed? Our Friday Guest is film star Lena Olin. Presenter Dave Russell. Producer Nathalie Rothschild.

item.title: 20 February 2014
item.description: The centre-right government is usually a big fan of tax cuts but has this morning announced a range of tax rises on everyday items. Money is one of the reasons why Swedish piglets are being shipped off to be slaughtered in Poland. Some say this means worse treatment for the pigs, and harder times for Swedish farmers. Staying on food related issues, we hear from a researcher how your body may be affected by what your grandparents ate, or did not eat. And we finish with even older ancestors. Ancient Egyptian mummies. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Nathalie Rothschild.

item.description: Swedish Foreign Minister Carl Bildt says Ukraine`s president had "blood on his hands" following renewed clashes in Kiev. We hear about the Green Party`s priorities ahead of the EU election, and we find out what makes Swedish people laugh.

item.title: 11 February 2014
item.description: A police chief says to us she would like to lock up about 300 people, one percent of the local population of two Stockholm suburbs. Then the issue of beggars from Romania. Who should do more? Sweden? Romania? The EU? We hear voices on this debate. And who is running the EU by the end of the year will be affected by the upcoming EU parliament election, held in Sweden on May 25th. A new poll has some surprising results. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Markus Landén.

item.title: 10th February 2014
item.description: The reform that put local authorities in charge of the schools was a failure according to a new evaluation. There`s regret in Sweden at the Swiss referendum result to limit EU immigration. A new Swedish website is making the social media site Facebook is more accessible to the visually and aurally impaired and we take a look at the new TV rom-com Welcome To Sweden, that gives an American point of view of Sweden.

item.description: The first 12 names to be inducted in the Swedish Music Hall of Fame. Abba`s Benny Andersson is our Friday guest! And how about the watch that counts down to your death by the exact second. Producer Loukas Christadoulou. Presented by Dave Russell

item.description: In today`s podcast - the battle of the sexes, Paralympic athletes preview, Friday Guest and who will be Sweden`s Song for Europe? Producer Kris Boswell/Presenter Dave Russell.

item.title: 5th February 2014
item.description: A new proposal could mean the end of anonymous donations to political parties in Sweden. We find out which artists have been given the government`s seal of approval with its annual music export prize. And with just two days to go until the Winter Olympics start in Sochi, we get a feel of the atmosphere in the Swedish camp.

item.title: 4th February 2014
item.description: The World Health Organisation warns that one in three will get cancer. It`s a huge debate in the UK, but how problematic has the freedom of movement within the EU been for Sweden? And we hear from two of Sweden`s biggest medal hopes in the Winter Olympics, the curlers!

item.title: 3 February 2014
item.description: Sweden needs to increase transparency into political party funding and municipal procurements according to the EU commission. A government report says that people of sub-Saharan African descent in Sweden, are the minority most often targeted by hate crimes. How a project to improve hand hygiene helped save millions of kroner in west Sweden The lack of large, mature woods with old decaying trees is threatening the survival of the white-backed woodpecker. Music: Yohio Heartbreak Hotel Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: 31st January 2014
item.description: A new poll shows record low numbers for the Swedish Center-right Party.The artist behind the controversial vagina mural was attacked while working on a new piece. We visit a school outside of Stockholm that accepts new refugees from Syria almost every day. And we hear from this week`s Friday guest Ji Nilsson, whose music got popular overnight. Presenter: Markus Landén.

item.title: 30th January 2014
item.description: New Swedish study: extra antioxidants for mice with lung cancer makes the cancer worse. Efforts to cut down on prescribing antibiotics seem to be working. Politicians continue to grapple with the country`s laws regarding rape. Meet some of the contestants who have dared to compete in Swedish Master Chef. And what happens if you dial the wrong number when you`re trying to buy a subway ticket in Stockholm. Producer / Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: 29th January 2014
item.description: Will adding a consent clause to Sweden`s rape laws help? One organization is skeptical. A group calls for better representation in Swedish society for those with ethnic backgrounds. And just before the start of the 2014 Winter Olympics, one researcher in Sweden finds that timing really is everything. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Producer: Ulla Engberg.

item.title: 28th January 2014
item.description: A former Sweden Democrat accuses the party of applying for party donations for a women`s association before it even existed. A car ad featuring footballer and star striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic has gone viral on the internet, but does it also say something about Sweden? The Data Inspectorate says the constitution needs to be changed to stop the website that lets Swedes check each other`s criminal records. And we visit a brewery specialising in craft beer in Stockholm. Producer: Ulla Engberg. Presenter: Markus Landén.

item.title: 27 January 2014
item.description: The Swedish website launched today which enables you to check if your neighbour has been convicted of rape or any other crime for that matter. How social media is helping youngsters suffering and recovering from eating disorders to connect with their peers.

item.title: 24th January 2014
item.description: Two students convicted in bullying case at elite school. Mille Markovic, notorious within the criminal underworld, shot dead. Shortage of midwives could endanger mothers and babies. Man finds creative way to deal with the many people accidentally dialing his number to buy subway tickets. Special Friday guest is artist and award-winning filmmaker, Anna Odell, whose movie Återträffen (The Reunion) just won a Guldbagge for best film. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Dave Russell.

item.title: 23rd January 2014
item.description: Plenty of flavour in today`s programme. A new study shows how one of Sweden`s best loved berries could lead the fight against obesity. There`s calls to boycott a Swedish hamburger chain which advised its workers on the parties to vote against at the general election. Food and votes are also in the mix as we meet some of the contestants of this year`s Masterchef. While in sports we speak to the Somali bandy team from Sweden bound to make history in the World Bandy Championships next week. Producer: Dave Russell. Presenter: Markus Landén.

item.title: 22nd January 2014
item.description: A clarification in the Swedish asylum laws will make it easier for vulnerable children to get asylum. We hear how many Swedish retirement homes won`t be able to show the upcoming Winter Olympics next month. It`s less than four months until the elections to the European Parliament - but are Swedish politicians paying enough attention to European issues? And we hear how Swedish supermarket chain ICA is hoping to lure Norwegians across the border to buy groceries. Producer: Dave Russell. Presenter: Markus Landén.

item.description: Should Romania foot the bill for its citizens begging in the Swedish capital? Rundown of the Swedish Film Awards. Choosing who will care for you in your own home is a tricky issue for many elderly. Sweden`s most popular given names. Sweden`s first Formula 1 racecar driver in more than 20 years. And find out why someone would shut themselves into a giant ice cube. Producer: Dave Russell. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: 20th January 2014
item.description: It`s wakey-wakey time for the European Space Agency`s Rosetta probe, and scientists here in Sweden are ready and waiting for the first signal. The government has announced new legislation to stop forced marriages. And then tonight is the big night for Swedish film. We take a look at the runners and riders in the 2014 Guldbagge Swedish Film awards.

item.title: 17th January 2014
item.description: Two more political parties in Stockholm say no to the 2022 Winter Olympic bid, so is that the end of the road for the bid? Foreign Minister Carl Bildt recently got into hot water here after a tweet following the death of Ariel Sharon, but what should politicians say when other politicians die? And then we meet a journalist, writer, conference moderator and film critic. And she`s also blind. Anna Bergholtz.

item.title: 16th January 2014
item.description: A demonstration against sexual violence could draw thousands in Sweden. A terrorism expert tells us what the country can do to fight extremism. Scientists from Uppsala help uncover dinosaurs in Saudi Arabia. And at least 3 Swedes are heading to the World Cup. Not as players, but as referees. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Producer: Nathalie Rothschild.

And Swedish artists see poverty up close and personal. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Producer: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: 14th January 2014
item.description: Education minister Jan Björklund announces an international commission on Swedish school today, but not everyone is convinced it will help. A professor gives his solution for beggars in Stockholm: no more handouts. And is reality TV featuring a Swede heading for the Red Planet? Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Producer: Markus Landén.

item.title: 13th January 2014
item.description: Sweden`s Sports Minister will not go to the opening of the Olympic Games in protest against what she says is an attempt to deflect attention from Russia`s poor human rights record. 8 months left to the elections and the government alliance is far behind in the polls. A new big brewery comes to Stockholm - should the smaller, local ones be worried? And a new daily newspaper is hitting the newsstands in Sweden - we look at its chances of survival. Presenter: Ulla Engberg Music: Mando Diao "Black Saturday"

item.description: Time`s running out for the Somali bandy team from Sweden, who might not get their visas in time for the first game. A Swedish football club is getting millions to teach footballers from Libya about democracy. And pop star and former professional dancer Anton Ewald tells us why he traded in his dancing shoes for a microphone. Producer: Kris Boswell. Presenter: Markus Landén.

Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Music Nyår by Emil Jensen & Familjen.

Music: Britney Spears "Oops.. I did it again" Presenter: Ulla Engberg Producer: Loukas Christodoulou
item.itunes:summary: Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt heads for Nelson Mandela`s funeral in South Africa - but questions are now asked where his party stood during the apartheid years. Millions of EU agricultural money goes to an unlikely beneficiary in Sweden. Nurses are sounding the alarm over staff shortages. And "wolf attacks" on sheep that are carried out by dogs. Music: Britney Spears "Oops.. I did it again" Presenter: Ulla Engberg Producer: Loukas Christodoulou
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 6th December 2013
item.description: Nelson Mandela has passed away. An anti-apartheid activist shares her memories of meeting the former South African president. Storm Sven barrels through Sweden today. And we hear about the world`s fastest growing currency, Bitcoin. Producer: Nathalie Rothschild. Presenter: Markus Landén.
item.itunes:summary: Nelson Mandela has passed away. An anti-apartheid activist shares her memories of meeting the former South African president. Storm Sven barrels through Sweden today. And we hear about the world`s fastest growing currency, Bitcoin. Producer: Nathalie Rothschild. Presenter: Markus Landén.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 5th December 2013
item.description: Documents leaked by Edward Snowden say Sweden is a "unique" source of intelligence on Russia for the USA. We hear how a children`s TV programme has been pulled into the Russia-Sweden propaganda war. French politicians voted yes to Swedish-style sex-trade laws. We hear from one researcher who says Sweden`s similar law has not helped sex workers. A home for older people has just opened in Stockholm - the twist is it`s specifically for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. And we`ll also open another window on our advent callendar. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Nathalie Rothschild.

item.title: 4th December 2013
item.description: Sweden`s biggest opinion poll gives the ruling centre-right coalition a headache. More on the controversy as one of Sweden`s most famous hip hop artists gets a prize in parliament. More prize news as the P3 Guld music award nominees are announced. And then we open another window in this year`s Radio Sweden Advent calendar.

item.title: Radio Sweden 3rd December 2013
item.description: ___POD: In today`s programme: Sweden`s education system gets low marks - again - in the latest Pisa rankings. A warning for anyone with old Swedish bank notes stuffed under their mattress, and Sweden`s most popular tourist attraction - the Vasa, a warship that sank on its maiden voyage in 1628 is facing a new battle - with its own weight. All this and more, together with all today`s top news stories.

Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Dave Russell. Music: Something More by Makthaverskan.

Does Sweden goes far enough to help the elderly when it comes to mental illness? Hear about a big sports event that specifically welcomes LGBTQ athletes. And find out whether soccer star Zlatan Ibrahimovic has a chance to win a book prize. Producer: Dave Russell. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: 26th November 2013
item.description: Two Swedish journalists have been seized in Syria. We hear from the doctor who helped a former cancer sufferer give birth following an ovarian tissue transplant, a unique first in Sweden. There`s a call for private debts to be wiped clean after 15 years. And a Brazilian student offers help assembling IKEA furniture in a bid to make friends. Producer: David Russell. Presenter: Markus Landén.

item.title: 25 Nov 2013
item.description: Why only two out of ten reported cases of domestic violence in Sweden lead to a conviction. It was supposed to ease the burden of the usual emergency number 112 - but have you even heard of 113 13? Lunch at ten thirty? That`s what many of the nation`s school kids are having. Scandinavian gender-neutral toy-catalogues causing a furore in France And in Sweden, multi-storey houses made out of wood is coming back into fashion. Music: Avicii Hey Brother Producer: Dave Russell Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: 22nd November 2013
item.description: Sweden has opened its first senior housing facility for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender people in central Stockholm. The comet so many of us were hoping to be a blinder, might actually turn out to be a damp squib. And then later in the programme we meet editor Malin Crona who tells us about her newspaper, 8 Sidor, written in easy to read Swedish.

item.title: 21st November 2013
item.description: We hear about changes in the law to keep documents from, for example, the European Union, more secret. There`s red faces at a major department store after they published offensive black faces in their catalogue. Some childrens books from the 1950s have been republished, and one swiftly pulled, because of some stoneage racism. We hear how children who face abuse and bullying are being divided up unfairly, based on what kind of names they`re called. And we take a walk outside to find some art that`s escaped the gallery. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Nathalie Rothchild.

We hear from the Swede who`s applied for asylum in her own country because she feels Jews are being persecuted here. Why the treatment of a doll in a children`s programme has caused uproar among parents.

item.title: 19th November 2013
item.description: Police are to get near-instant access to telephone and internet metadata, without a court order. We hear from a legal expert who`s critical. Corruption in Uppsala council, we hear how apartments were allegedly handed out to friends and relatives. A Swedish member of the European parliament is campaigning for students to be able to stay in a foreign EU country after they`ve graduated. A report says that music may be one of the things that can help cancer patients. I ask a colleague at Sport Radio just how much of a chance do Sweden`s footballers have this evening. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Markus Landén.

item.description: As the clean-up operation after the super-typhoon in the Philippines gets underway, Swedish organisations are doing what they can to help. In Stockholm, plans for nine new metro stations and tens of thousands new flats are unveiled - but will it be enough? Should the EU do more to help EU migrants who are homeless in cities in Sweden and elsewhere? A job in a restaurant is not always a springboard onto the labour market in Sweden. And Environment minister Lena Ek ahead of the UN climate talk in Warzaw that starts today. Presenter: Ulla Engberg Producer: Kris Boswell Music: Laleh "Elephant"

item.title: 9th October 2013
item.description: Day three of the Nobel week, and today it was time for the Chemistry Prize A Swedish newspaper claims to have created a favourite to win tomorrows nobel prize in literature. At least in the betting world. The mosque in Örebro has been attacked by angry relatives of some of the young Somali Swedes who have gone to Syria to fight. We hear reactions from the local community. Presenter: Ulla Engberg Music: Laleh "Coulours"

item.description: Nobel Prize week begins - We`ve all the reaction and analysis - also Spotify celebrates 5 years streaming music. Presenter Dave Russell.

item.title: 4th October 2013
item.description: As Russia widens its ban on adoptions to countries that allow same-sex marriage, a Swedish singer launches a campaign to support Russia`s LGBT community...We speak to a woman who challenges stereotypes about gamers - apparently they`re not all geeky guys living in their parents` basements...And our Friday guest is Henrik Fexeus, a performer of psychological magic. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Dave Russell.

item.title: 3rd October 2013
item.description: A Swede numbers among the Greenpeace activists charged in Russia with piracy for protesting Arctic drilling. The elite boarding school that had been shut by the authorities because of bullying will get to stay open, but the shenanigans continue. The pros and cons of blocking kids from seeing certain websites. Ahead of tomorrow, Cinnamon Bun day, we visit a bakery preparing to make thousands of these sweet treats. Then we go to the movies to hear about the latest documentary by Maud Nycander. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Dave Russell.

item.title: 2nd October 2013
item.description: The reactor at Oskarshamn is finally back online again after getting clogged with jellyfish. Two shadow budget proposals from Swedish opposition parties. The latest advice on whether to vaccinate yourself against the flu this year. A choir that welcomes everyone, regardless of their ability to sing, draws hundreds of people. And finally, should Stockholm host the winter olympics in 2022?

item.title: 1st October 2013
item.description: A Swedish citizen facing terror charges in the US claims he was tortured. Representatives of the Roma community meet with the government following the secret poilce register scandal. Also did you know that Sweden`s the best place in the world to grow old? And why the Abba Museum in Stockholm is collaborating with two guitar loving brothers in Umeå.

item.title: 30th September 2013
item.description: Should religious circumcision on minors be banned in Sweden? The children`s ombudsman says yes, but members of the Muslim and Jewish communities say no. A much publicised not-guilty verdict in a gang-rape case raises questions about Swedish law. And do you throw old clothes away? Many of us don`t, but why not?

item.title: 27th September 2013
item.description: The International Panel on Climate Change presented its latest report in Stockholm, warning that it was more certain than ever that humans were the cause of global warming. We speak to Swedish parents who want politicians to do more, and are willing to take it to the ballot box. Then later in the programme, Stockholm City Council promises to help homeless EU citizens on the streets of the capital during the winter, and how travel agencies are gearing up for the Autumn half-term holiday.

item.title: 26th September 2013
item.description: This year’s Right Livelihood Awards go for campaigners against chemical weapons and sexual violence against women in war, a Palestinian human rights lawyer, and a food expert who saved 20 million lives by releasing wasps over Africa. But does giving a prize make a difference? A meeting here on how the international community can deal with the crisis in Syria. Is Sweden’s traditional reliance on the UN realistic? A discovery that tick bites can cause allergies to meat, concerns over the health effects of e-cigarettes, and the effect of divorce on children.

item.title: 25th September 2013
item.description: A number of Swedish police officers have spoken out about the police discrimination against Roma people and how to move on. The Swedish government has sold off its last shares in the Nordic region`s largest banking group Nordea Surveillance is in the spotlight as researchers, journalists and academics put their heads together at an Internet privacy seminar in Stockholm. And Sweden`s most famous soccer player Zlatan Ibrahimovic says he`ll end his career at Paris Saint Germaine.

item.description: Pressure mounts on Swedish police as a second secret Roma database is exposed...Part of Sweden`s development aid budget has gone to paying a minister`s salary... As lobster season kicks off, a new drive to brand Sweden as a top food destination. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Dave Russell. Music: "Dancing On My Own" by Robyn.

item.description: Shock and surprise as Swedish police turns out to have illegally registered Roma people. Climate change is on the agenda again as the UN climate panel is meeting in Stockholm It is 12 years ago today that the Swedish journalist Davit Isaak was imprisoned in Eritrea. Producer: Nathalie Rothschild Presenter: Markus Landén Music: Daniel Adams-Ray "Precis som jag"

item.description: A Christian woman`s appointment as Labor Market Minister has stirred up a heated debate about religion and politics...Are medical check-ups a waste of time and money?...A musical mystery is solved as Swedish Radio reveals who`s behind a song that took the internet by storm….Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Markus Landén. Music: "The Opposite of Hallelujah" by Jens Lekman.

item.title: 18th September 2013
item.description: It`s budget day in Sweden, we`ll be looking at the winners and the losers & with parlt open for business again with next year`s election looming on the horizon, we meet politicians from across the party divide to hear their expectations for the next 12 months. Presenter Dave Russell.

item.title: 17th September 2013
item.description: Today the Swedish parliament reopens after its summer break. Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt presents government policy and announces a reshuffle. Some Swedish rats are becoming immune to rat poison. Simulated civil war on Gotland, as German paratroopers land on the Swedish island to secure the airport and rescue civilians. We hear from an author who says too many Swedish kids are badly brought up. And Swedish bumblebee queens are ruling new nests in Britain.

item.title: 16th September 2013
item.description: As 700 Chilean villagers sue a Swedish mining company for toxic pollution, we talk to the documentary film maker who first uncovered their plight. New survey shows parents of pre-school children are unhappy with groups sizes. The government comes in for criticism for how it is treating the indigenous Sami people. Sweden`s King Carl Gustaf celebrates 40 years on the throne. Music: Lars Winnerbäck "Jag får liksom ingen ordning" Presenter: Ulla Engberg Producer: Kris Boswell

item.title: 13th September 2013
item.description: We hear about the election held by the biggest church in Sweden is holding on Sunday. A suspected massacre on a Swedish island - but we hear it probably happened over 1,500 years ago. One of the key figures in the US Civil Rights struggle speaks to us, Gloria Karlmark, one of the Little Rock Nine. And we take a trip to one of Stockholm`s museums, to hear about its new African exhibition. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Dave Russell.

There is heavy criticism of changes in the way newspapers are state-subsidised. We hear what kind of school life some politicians had. And we end with a report on the new Monica Zetterlund film. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: 11th September 2013
item.description: A special edition of the programme, dominated by the ten-year anniversary of the death of Foreign Minister Anna Lindh: Some say she could have risen to become prime minister. We hear from people who knew her well, like fellow Social Democrat Mona Sahlin, and we get the reaction from members of the public. We also hear about the man who murdered her. Why did he do it, and where is he now? Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: George Wood.

Research in HIV AIDS has made some great strides, but there is still a long way to go to find a cost effective and safe cure. And then Sweden is home to a booming games industry, where does it go from here?

item.title: 23th August 2013
item.description: New proposals could mean more wolves in Sweden, but also make it easier to hunt them. Today marks 40 years since the bank siege that coined the term "Stockholm Syndrome". What is it? What happened? And could it happen again today? And then our Friday guest is one of Sweden`s leading young milliners, that`s a hat designer to you and me. We meet Malinda Damgaard.

item.title: 21 Aug 2013
item.description: Clashes between police and protesters outside Jokkmokk, where a mining company wants to drill for minerals. The Sami people calls it the most active colonisation of their area ever. And on the island of Öland even the local council is against prospective drilling there - but it seems there is not much they can do to stop it. Freedom of choice is supposed to help us find the right health centre - but how do we make that choice? And, on the day when the bear hunt starts up north, we take a look at the state of this country`s carnivore population.

item.description: More meat cheating uncovered. People in the city of Gothenburg are angry that they can no longer party all night long. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Kris Boswell.

item.title: 19th August 2013
item.description: Rainbow painted fingernails dominated much of the Swedish coverage of the World Athletics Championships in Moscow, but what impact will they have on a movement seen by many here as homophobic. Hundreds of people take part in an Asylum March across the country. And then another instance of people taking a stand, as women don headscarves to protest against what they call the daily abuse of women in Sweden who choose to wear the veil.

item.description: Swedes continue to travel to Syria to fight with jihadists against the Bashir regime. A play has premiered, based on a book written by the current prime minister twenty years ago. Sweden takes a gold medal at the World Championships in Athletics and Track and Field. And at this week`s We are Stockholm festival we visit the batting cages to learn about baseball and softball in Sweden.

Swedish athletes are making a subtle but serious protest against homophobia in Russia. And look out - Sweden`s most disgusting delicacy is here again - the fermented herring known as surströmming. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Brett Ascarelli.

item.description: Concern about vulnerability to foreign snooping after the revelation that several Swedish political parties have their e-mail servers in the United States. This month marks 60 years of Swedish observers on the border between North and South Korea...and one in ten 16 year old boys here look at pornography daily. And the fashion labels of future on show at the Rookie Awards. Presenter: Tom Sullivan Producer: Brett Ascarelli

item.description: In today`s programme, does President Obama`s upcoming visit to Stockholm herald a new era in US-Swedish relations? Boxer Frida Wallberg faces the media for the first time on her fight back from a devastating brain hemorrhage. Also, why are Swedes who fear they`ve caught Lyme Disease heading abroad for treatment? Steps are taken to save the endangered white-backed woodpecker; and we hear how a group of researchers are retracing the steps of pioneering Swedes who settled in modern-day Namibia and Angola.

item.title: 7th August 2013
item.description: The policeman behind the fatal shooting said to have sparked the riots in Husby gets let off. Women working at Thai massage parlors are fed up with requests for happy endings. Upsalite, the "impossible" substance. New student housing in Lund. Scandinavians fixated with "boring TV". Producer: Dave Russell. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

A car crash with a happy ending: birth. And whether quality of life can keep up with stretching lifespans. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Dave Russell.

item.title: 5th August 2013
item.description: Why are government agencies selling our personal details to ad firms? The lack of student housing is leading to unexpected side-effects, like an explosion of bedbugs. We hear from the Swedes designing a new replica of the Titanic. And then straight talk about non-straight literature.

item.title: 2nd August 2013
item.description: A new study shows Swedish parents find it tough juggling work and family life. Why did a Syrian artist, due to play in Stockholm, get his visa refused? Pride continues in Stockholm, with some happy couples tying the knot at drop-in weddings. And we speak to a politician that has taken the front line in the fight for gay rights, EU minister Birgitta Ohlsson.

item.title: 1st August 2013
item.description: Why do complaints of anti-Semitism and other hate crimes continue to rise in the southern Swedish city of Malmö? Dangers of high-fat, low-carb diets, the right of public access versus commercial exploitation of nature. And where does freedom of religion fit into the new school law? And is there a freedom not to dance?

item.title: 30th July 2013
item.description: Stockholm Pride kicks off today, but many will be thinking of events across the Baltic at the parties and seminars. Sweden`s economy is still sluggish. There`s research at the Swedish space base above the Arctic Circle, looking for a way to reduce the sonic booms when jets pass the speed of sound. And we profile what would be a major Swedish city, if only the Swedes there lived in this country, London.

And tomorrow sees Royal Wedding fever hit Stockholm, as the King and Queen`s youngest child Madeleine marries her British/American fiancé Chris in a more relaxed ceremony, well relaxed for the Royals, that is.

item.title: 4th June 2013
item.description: There's just been some unusually harsh criticism of what two people did while at the top of the Swedish government. Some people have been sent to prison today, who thought they were fighting witchcraft. They've been found guilty of abuse. And then it's the controversial issue of genetic engineering, and why Sweden is one of the few places where this research is happening Finishing off with a report on the team of Swedes who'll be off to represent this country at the winter paralympics in Russia. And that'll mean playing curling from a wheelchair. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Nick Chipperfield.
item.itunes:summary: There's just been some unusually harsh criticism of what two people did while at the top of the Swedish government. Some people have been sent to prison today, who thought they were fighting witchcraft. They've been found guilty of abuse. Plus there`s two new names on the calendar of name days in Sweden. Is it even important to celebrate a name day? And we`ll have time to also hear about how bad strawberries are still dangerous. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Dave Russell.

Host: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Fallskärm by Timbuktu Feat Eboi & Jonas Rensfeldt this is the (L-Wiz Remix)
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 27th March 2012
item.description: We talk to someone whose job is to help people leave a life of organised crime behind. She helps them start a new life and escape possible reprisals. In the newspapers you can see that the status of teachers here has taken another knock, since it is reported that even poorly qualified students can get a place on a training course. The head of the teachers` union tells us that things have been getting worse, since the 1970s. We have a report on how people from the Roma community are still being sent back to Kosovo, despite fears they face persecution. And we hear about the winner of the world`s biggest prize for children`s books. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: George Wood.

item.title: 26th March, 2013
item.description: A report confirms fears that a mass swine flu vaccination drive here led to an increase in a serious disease among children. The word ungooglable is also unacceptable – at least to the internet giant. And the government wants all Swedish schools to offer Chinese. Some are leading by example. Presenter: Sven Carlsson, Producer: George Wood, Music: `www.Naimachat.se` by Hans Appelqvist

Stockholm goes green, but we`re not talking about the environment and our Friday guest has been called Sweden`s Adele.

We report on an analysis of changes that because of Sweden`s private-run free schools. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Brett Ascarelli.

item.description: As a result of the U.S. led invasion of Iraq ten years ago, Sweden took in thousands of refugees. We speak to one of them. The Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces says Sweden should offer asylum to interpreters in Afghanistan. The tourist federation revises its goal for tourist income down by SEK 12 billion. We speak to a man whose getting ready sail around the world in a tiny boat. Robbers steal a giant clam from a pet store. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Dave Russell.

Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Tom Sullivan.

item.title: 11th March, 2013
item.description: ---POD: A Welsh worker's daughter who married Swedish royalty - princess Lilian dies at age 97 It's hard to get a house in Sweden – and even harder when public housing companies put tough demands on tenants And Turkey's first ever state visit to Stockholm – is Sweden in it for human rights or business? We'll also be looking more closely at Sweden's entry to the Eurovision song contest, and play you a new single from a former Abba great. Presenter: Sven Hultberg Carlsson, Producer: Tom Sullivan, Music: Agnetha Fältskog – 'When You Really Loved Someone'

Sweden`s athletics federation names its first ever female national team coach And our Friday guest today is writer/director Lisa James Larsson whose debut feature film has been topping the swedish charts

item.title: 1st March 2013
item.description: The migration authorities want to help abused women who come here from abroad to be with Swedish men. With the horse meat scandal continuing, he ask the Minister for Agriculture how food packaging should be labeled. The Swedish nuclear industry would reportedly have to pay five times as much as it does today to truly cover the expenses of closing old reactors. And in our Friday interview, we talk to Robert Hårdh, head of the human rights group Civil Rights Defenders, and incidently one of the few real people to be mentioned by name in Stieg Larsson’s Millennium trilogy.

We hear about how one comedian is giving immigrants and Swedes stage therapy, with his improv show about culture shock in Sweden. Plus a report from a museum exhibition about hair. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Gabriel Stein.

This week, Swedes can drop off their guns with the police, no questions asked. The Pirate Bay has to pull up its anchor and head for other shores, as the Swedish Pirate Party backs down over web access. And, what`s a student to do when financial aid isn`t enough to cover their basic expenses? Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Nathalie Rothschild.

item.description: Women from Syria who oppose the regime gather in Stockholm to pave the way for what they hope will be a better future. Swedish researchers tell the world that the link between hormone-distubring chemicals -- and illness is stronger than we`d once thought. The media has been blaring about the financial troubles of a new mine in Pajala--how do locals see it? At just 15, Irene Ekelund has already broken a Swedish track record--how far can she go? Some restaurants are charging for a glass of tap water.

Presenter: George Wood Producer: Gabriel Stein

And an exhibition in Stockholm looks at just how Jewish Jesus was. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Tom Sullivan.

And the world`s best footballer is in town....but with Zlatan around, who`ll come out on top...

The northern city of Umeå preps for its year in the spotlight as the next European Capital of Culture. item.title: 10th January 2013
item.description: We try to get some answers as to why the US took two Swedish citizens from Africa, and flew them to New York to face terrorism charges. The leader of Sweden`s Center Party has cut short her holiday, as some leading members protest against some new policy proposals. We talk to a grassroots member of the party. Do you think the Swedish trains are no good, suffering delays and cancellations when it starts to snow? Well this may be unfair - we hear that lots of other countries also have the same problems. And Swedes are spending millions to save the European eel, which risks being eaten into extinction. Presenter Loukas Christodoulou. Producer Gabriel Stein.

item.title: 2nd January 2013
item.description: The New Year sees new laws, we’ll take a look at some of the changes. And today sees the introduction of controversial congestion charges in Sweden’s second city, Gothenburg. With the new year, Sweden also takes over the presidency of the Nordic Council of Ministers. But what role does the council have when all the members are involved with the European Union? School visits to theaters are on the decline, are kids losing out on access to culture? And the authorities are concerned that many secondary schools, mostly private, aren’t fulfilling their responsibility to maintain libraries.

And street artists defy an anti-graffiti law and make an arty advent calendar on the streets of the Swedish capital.

item.description: Plenty of downward signs for the Swedish economy. Could social media boost Sweden`s readiness for disaster? A researcher says museums here are playing down Sweden`s imperial past. Host: Sven Hultberg Carlsson Closing Music: Albin Gromer, "Var Min Vän"

item.title: 16th November 2012
item.description: Ikea says it "deeply regrets" use of forced prison labour by suppliers in communist East Germany during the 1980`s. Swedes are the most unhealthy eaters in Scandinavia, according to a new report. We hear about a sausage renaissance here, and we meet one of Sweden`s most famous singers.

item.title: 14th November 2012
item.description: A dramatic day in politics as a damning video showing a top Sweden Democrat politician using racist and abusive language forces his resignation and leaves the party reeling 9 out of 10 unemployed don`t get the full 80 percent of their salary beause they make too much money...We hear from a jobless man affected in Gothenburg and the politician wanting to change the benefits system..

Second Swede inducted to NHL Hall of Fame, and Zlatan picks up Swedish Footballer of the Year. Presenter Brett Ascarelli. Producer Dave Russell.

item.title: 12th November 2012
item.description: Scandinavian airline SAS announce plans to slash wages and cut jobs in order to survive. But is it enough? Over 8000 children in Sweden have a parent locked up in prison. But what is being done to help these unseen victims of crime? And as tv adverts keep telling us, Christmas is just around the corner, and a very special Swedish TV tradition will soon be hitting our screens.

item.title: 9th November 2012
item.description: Proposals to give school teachers more training to deal with xenophobia in the classroom. What would a Common European Asylum System mean for Sweden? We meet Stieg Larsson Prize winner Maryam Al-Khawaja who calls on Sweden and Denmark to do more to help human rights in Bahrain. And how museum visitors were behind a hit Downton Abbey exhibition in a Stockholm museum.

item.title: 06 November 2012
item.description: We hear about how the bankrupt cash-handling company Panaxia may also have been involved in some serious fraud. In Sweden lay judges are part of deciding a criminal case; they`re often appointed by political parties. There`s been strong criticisms of this system. We hear more And we also hear about an effort to simply getting neighbours to say hello in the morning. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Dave Russell.

item.title: 5th November 2012
item.description: Sweden is about to host its first trial ever for genocide - for crimes committed in Rwanda. What can Sweden learn from other countries when it comes to getting jobs for its fastest growing immigrant group? With just one day to go to the US elections, we speak to one youth politician who`s in the States supporting Romney. And hear about the brand new Abba museum. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Kris Boswell.

item.description: Drugs that are supposed to help people quit heroin are getting into the hands of dealers, and they can be deadly. TV companies launch new services to crush online file sharing. But will it work? And, it`s hip to ride your bicycle these days, but it`s also dangerous. Now a new government report suggests ways to make riding your bike safer and more popular. Host: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: The Swedish House Mafia “Greyhound”

item.title: 31st October 2012
item.description: Happy Halloween! The ghostly goings on are still relatively new here in Sweden in historical terms and in today`s programme we`ll be speaking to the man whose American wife first brought the tradition here and ask Swedes if they celebrate the tradition. Also coming up on Radio Sweden, we hear from another Eriksson who`s landed one of the top coaching jobs in British sport And why free school lunches could be one of the reasons why Sweden has one of the highest divorce rates in Europe

item.title: 26 October 2012
item.description: The Sweden Democrats, best known for their anti-immigration policy, are scoring high in the latest poll. We talk to a senior member of the party. Sweden is two years away from an election. But Americans are only two weeks away. And we hear how Swedes are knocking on doors there to try to help Obama and Romney win. Then we talk to the man who cooked President Barack Obama`s first official state dinner. Marcus Samuelsson. Presenter: Gabriel Stein. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: 24 October 2012
item.description: Social Democrat leader, Stefan Löfven speaks out on the divisive issue of profit-making by welfare companies. he says he does not want to limit profits, but he does want the companies to open the books. Then we hear who has been chosen as business woman of the year by Ruter Dam. And we find out who will be presenting Sweden`s biggest TV programme next year - the Swedish song contest Melodifestivalen. Finishing off, we hear about some strange northern lights, which turn out to have a down-to-earth explanation Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Brett Ascarelli.

And we find out how the Church of Sweden is protecting its roofs from copper thieves.

item.title: 18 October 2012
item.description: Sweden is not so equal when it comes to health: women in their thirties are off sick from work twice as much as men. We hear from a nurse who say the hospital system is over-stretched. One of the people who chooses the Nobel Prize for Literature has been accused of profiting from this year`s decision, since he`s a translator of the winner`s works. One of the countries biggest iron mines near Pajala is breaking ground today. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Tom Sullivan.

item.title: October 11th 2012
item.description: Broadcasting live from outside the building at Medborgplatsen, a market square in Stockholm`s southside, Brett Ascarelli hosted a programme focusing on sport as a platform for integration. Taking place while several groups of youngsters partcipated in different sports as part of Stockholm`s centenary Olmpic celebrations, Brett speaks to a variety of guests, inlcuding coaches, athletes and experts to discuss ethnic diversity in sports from different perspectives. Presenter: Bret Ascarelli

item.title: October 10th 2012
item.description: We`re going to be hearing about Swedish food habits. First, we`ll meet up with a women who has dedicated her life to food. For 25 years, she ran the kitchens of one of Sweden`s largest super market chains. Then, we`ll talk to a doctor and the man behind the most popular health blog in the Nordics. He writes all about one of the most popular diet or lifestyle trends of our time: low carb high fat. We go out to the main bakery and distribution center of a growing Stockholm bakery chain. Presenter: Gabriel Stein

Thereare new revelations about the Swedish plans to help build a weapons factory in Saudi Arabia. We speak to investors about the controversial oil company Africa Oil. And, a new campaign to get women involved in peace processes.

item.description: The first of this year`s Nobel Prizes gets announced today in the area of medicine. And the next national election is still two years away, but that didn`t keep the leaders from debating some of the core issues in Sweden. Why school photos are making some parents snap. And as the northern town of Kiruna prepares to pick up and move east, we find out about the design competition to rebuild it. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.description: An upper court has pushed reset on one of the most expensive trials in Swedish history. A delegation from North Korea visits Sweden. What does it mean? And a look back on democracy in Sweden over the past hundred years.
