item.title: 21st September 2012
item.description: A swedish prosecutor finds that a government defency agency did pay cash to help set up a dummy company to help saudi arabia build an arms factory but no charges will be brought The Social Democrats perform a u-turn on a previous election pledge to scrap the government`s tax breaks for Swedes buying-in household help Find out why Swedes are rather fond of war And Glenn Hysen is our Friday guest
item.itunes:summary: A swedish prosecutor finds that a government defency agency did pay cash to help set up a dummy company to help saudi arabia build an arms factory but no charges will be brought The Social Democrats perform a u-turn on a previous election pledge to scrap the government`s tax breaks for Swedes buying-in household help Find out why Swedes are rather fond of war And Glenn Hysen is our Friday guest
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: September 20 2012
item.description: The government presents its stimulus budget. 23 billion kronor`s worth. What does it mean for you? A Swedish tabloid defends the publication of photos showing a British royal topless. And the telecom company Telia Sonera defends itself today against accusations or money laundering and bribery Host: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Stiftelsen, "Vart Jag En Går"
item.itunes:summary: The government presents its stimulus budget. 23 billion kronor`s worth. What does it mean for you? A Swedish tabloid defends the publication of photos showing a British royal topless. And the telecom company Telia Sonera defends itself today against accusations or money laundering and bribery Host: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Stiftelsen, "Vart Jag En Går"
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: September 19 2012
item.description: Another big consumer electronics company goes bust. What`s wrong with the industry? We talk to the Foreign Ministry to find out what they`re doing for the Swede sentenced to 8 years in Colombia for being an alleged member of FARC. A European Education Agency throws the book at Swedish colleges. Host: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Agnes, “Release Me”
item.itunes:summary: Another big consumer electronics company goes bust. What`s wrong with the industry? We talk to the Foreign Ministry to find out what they`re doing for the Swede sentenced to 8 years in Colombia for being an alleged member of FARC. A European Education Agency throws the book at Swedish colleges. Host: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Agnes, “Release Me”
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 18th September 2012
item.description: A new session of Parliament opens today, and we`ll find out what to expect from this season of politics. Surgeons in Sweden carried out the first mother-daughter womb transplant in the world this weekend. A security company gone bust is causing problems for other businesses and is now under investigation. Sweden`s opens its biggest embassy in a place you might not expect ... And it isn`t science fiction: A Swedish hospital is testing robot legs to help rehabilitate people with serious injuries. Host: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Tom Sullivan
item.itunes:summary: A new session of Parliament opens today, and we`ll find out what to expect from this season of politics. Surgeons in Sweden carried out the first mother-daughter womb transplant in the world this weekend. A security company gone bust is causing problems for other businesses and is now under investigation. Sweden`s opens its biggest embassy in a place you might not expect ... And it isn`t science fiction: A Swedish hospital is testing robot legs to help rehabilitate people with serious injuries. Host: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Tom Sullivan
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 17th September 2012
item.description: Should bad students get to skip the normal three years of high school and go for just one? The government thinks so. We speak to the Swedish industry and the teacher`s union to get their opinions. And who`s behind the material students are learning? We report on private-sector sponsorship in schools. Ex-government ministers still receive payouts long after they`ve finished their lawmaking duties. And Sweden`s video games industry is booming. Host: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Tom Sullivan.
item.itunes:summary: Should bad students get to skip the normal three years of high school and go for just one? The government thinks so. We speak to the Swedish industry and the teacher`s union to get their opinions. And who`s behind the material students are learning? We report on private-sector sponsorship in schools. Ex-government ministers still receive payouts long after they`ve finished their lawmaking duties. And Sweden`s video games industry is booming. Host: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Tom Sullivan.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 14th September 2012
item.description: We`ll hear from our reporter in place at this afternoon`s press conference Also in today`s half hour , the continuing hunt for the pickpocket caught on subway camera robbing a man lying unconscious on a train track And in our Friday Interview we debunk some of the myths surrounding the centuries old performance art Burlesque
item.itunes:summary: We`ll hear from our reporter in place at this afternoon`s press conference Also in today`s half hour , the continuing hunt for the pickpocket caught on subway camera robbing a man lying unconscious on a train track And in our Friday Interview we debunk some of the myths surrounding the centuries old performance art Burlesque
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 13 September 2012
item.description: Swedes eat too much fat and too little fruit and veg. How effective are Sweden`s anti-drug addiction programs? A man is robbed and left to be hit by an underground train. Do we need a law to force bystanders to help people in need? Presenter: Tom Sullivan Producer: Kris Boswell
item.itunes:summary: Swedes eat too much fat and too little fruit and veg. How effective are Sweden`s anti-drug addiction programs? A man is robbed and left to be hit by an underground train. Do we need a law to force bystanders to help people in need? Presenter: Tom Sullivan Producer: Kris Boswell
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 12th September 2012
item.description: Just how effective was the government in the release of two Swedish journalists from an Ethiopian prison this week? A Columbian-Swedish journalist is sentenced to prison in Columbia for alleged membership of the Farc guerilla group. Swedish higher education gets criticism for being both too fluffy and too practical. How does Sweden respond to smoke signals from the EU on the way cigarette packages might look in the future? And a look at whether the rainy, chilly summer will impact people who get the autumn blues. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Kris Boswell.

And a look at whether the rainy, chilly summer will impact people who get the autumn blues. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Kris Boswell.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 11th September 2012
item.description: Two Swedish journalists are set free from prison in Ethiopia. An inquiry into public service radio and TV recommends a tax instead of the current license fee. And Sweden`s central bank unveils new coins… Presenter: Tom Sullivan Producer: Kris Boswell
item.itunes:summary: Two Swedish journalists are set free from prison in Ethiopia. An inquiry into public service radio and TV recommends a tax instead of the current license fee. And Sweden`s central bank unveils new coins… Presenter: Tom Sullivan Producer: Kris Boswell
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: September 10th 2012
item.description: Unemployment benefits go unchanged for 6 years. Stockholm`s airport grows, but not without pains. Wraup of the Paralympic Games Host: Gabriel Stein
item.itunes:summary: Unemployment benefits go unchanged for 6 years. Stockholm`s airport grows, but not without pains. Wraup of the Paralympic Games Host: Gabriel Stein
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 6th September 2012
item.description: The Swedish Central Bank made the decision to cut interest rates - but an analyst tells us this still might be too little, too late. We also hear from the mayor of Södertälje. A city that once took a record number of Iraqi refugees, and is now struggling to cope with people seeking refuge from the conflict in Syria. Presenter: Loukas Christoodulou. Producer: Gabriel Stein.
item.itunes:summary: The Swedish Central Bank made the decision to cut interest rates - but an analyst tells us this still might be too little, too late. We also hear from the mayor of Södertälje. A city that once took a record number of Iraqi refugees, and is now struggling to cope with people seeking refuge from the conflict in Syria. Presenter: Loukas Christoodulou. Producer: Gabriel Stein.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 5th September 2012
item.description: A report says that last year`s Afghanistan attack that killed a Swede was caused by the actions of agents working for the USA. Problems with the new system of de-regulated pharmacies; some people find it hard to get their prescriptions filled. Then it`s piracy - people are not just copying films and books, but also furniture. Following on from yesterday`s report, about a World War Two airman`s grave that is being looked after by a mysterious well-wisher, we hear about the son of the dead RAF man, and his search for the truth. And a new film about Swedish prime minister Olof Palme is out. We hear what it has to say about this man, who was loved, and hated as well, by Swedes. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Gabriel Stein.

Problems with the new system of de-regulated pharmacies; some people find it hard to get their prescriptions filled. Then it`s piracy - people are not just copying films and books, but also furniture. Following on from yesterday`s report, about a World War Two airman`s grave that is being looked after by a mysterious well-wisher, we hear about the son of the dead RAF man, and his search for the truth. And a new film about Swedish prime minister Olof Palme is out. We hear what it has to say about this man, who was loved, and hated as well, by Swedes. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Gabriel Stein.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 4th September 2012
item.description: Should parents wanting to hire after-school tutors for their kids be given tax breaks? The government promises yet more cash in the upcoming budget for youth training. And who is taking care of the Swedish grave of a British bomber pilot shot down during the war? All that and more in this half-hour from Radio Sweden.
item.itunes:summary: Should parents wanting to hire after-school tutors for their kids be given tax breaks? The government promises yet more cash in the upcoming budget for youth training. And who is taking care of the Swedish grave of a British bomber pilot shot down during the war? All that and more in this half-hour from Radio Sweden.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 3rd September 2012
item.description: A deal to buy the assets of bankrupt Saab Autos is finalised, speeding up the process of producing electric cars from Trollhättan Drivers though will have to step off the gas as Sweden`s traffic chiefs want to double the number of speed cameras in the country Who loves the welfare state? We meet some of the researchers who investigate the consequences for individuals and society of the systems for getting sick people back to work. In sport, Sweden says farewell to one of its greatest ever athletes who retired on Sunday And it`s the first Monday in September, which can only mean one thing, the start of the Swedish Elk hunting season
item.itunes:summary: A deal to buy the assets of bankrupt Saab Autos is finalised, speeding up the process of producing electric cars from Trollhättan Drivers though will have to step off the gas as Sweden`s traffic chiefs want to double the number of speed cameras in the country Who loves the welfare state? We meet some of the researchers who investigate the consequences for individuals and society of the systems for getting sick people back to work. In sport, Sweden says farewell to one of its greatest ever athletes who retired on Sunday And it`s the first Monday in September, which can only mean one thing, the start of the Swedish Elk hunting season
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 31st August 2012
item.description: Despite millions of dollars in investment to bring in a fairer system of marking, Sweden`s national high school exams still don`t pass the test While at university, the introduction of tuition fees for students from abroad is said to be damaging Sweden`s competitiveness in the global market We meet Jonas Gardell, the author of a new tv series which looks back at the 80`s and the impact of HIV and aids on the gay community And in our Friday interview, we hear from the former Swedish international goalkeeper Magnus Hedman on the drugs, the sex buying arrest and the depression that led him to the brink of suicide..
item.itunes:summary: Despite millions of dollars in investment to bring in a fairer system of marking, Sweden`s national high school exams still don`t pass the test While at university, the introduction of tuition fees for students from abroad is said to be damaging Sweden`s competitiveness in the global market We meet Jonas Gardell, the author of a new tv series which looks back at the 80`s and the impact of HIV and aids on the gay community And in our Friday interview, we hear from the former Swedish international goalkeeper Magnus Hedman on the drugs, the sex buying arrest and the depression that led him to the brink of suicide..
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 30th August 2012
item.description: Far more women are developing a problem with gambling. On Gotland there`s a battle for the trees, as bands of protestors play cat and mouse with police over a proposed mine. Work by controversial artist Lars Vilks has been banned from an art museum, causing the whole exhibition to be cancelled. For art dealers in Sweden, a case in the USA could have an impact on how they sell photos. We end with a report on the possible health benefits of chocolate. Music: Hellsongs, "School`s Out" Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou Producer: Dave Russell

item.title: 29th August 2012
item.description: Is the deal to sell Swedish fighter jets to Switzerland really worth it? The government announces billion dollar investments in faster trains, but not fast enough, some say. And one of the big tv hits of last year is back on Swedish screens soon, as Swedish-Americans find out more about their Swedish roots. All that and more in this half-hour from Radio Sweden.

And one of the big tv hits of last year is back on Swedish screens soon, as Swedish-Americans find out more about their Swedish roots. All that and more in this half-hour from Radio Sweden.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 28th August 2012
item.description: Switzerland agrees to buy 22 new Super Jas Gripen fighter jets from Sweden. Why is it so difficult to get a comfy smooth ride on public transport? Today sees Paul Simon and cellist Yo Yo Ma receive the Polar Music Prize. All that and Stockholm Fashion Week in this half-hour from Radio Sweden
item.itunes:summary: Switzerland agrees to buy 22 new Super Jas Gripen fighter jets from Sweden. Why is it so difficult to get a comfy smooth ride on public transport? Today sees Paul Simon and cellist Yo Yo Ma receive the Polar Music Prize. All that and Stockholm Fashion Week in this half-hour from Radio Sweden
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 27th August 2012
item.description: Could changes in the education system be behind undemocratic values amongst Sweden`s kids? Sweden`s intelligence service are under fire after a James Bond-themed party, And SAAB`s former owner are set to team up with the Chinese company that weren`t allowed to buy the Swedish carmaker. All that and more in today`s programme from Radio Sweden!
item.itunes:summary: Could changes in the education system be behind undemocratic values amongst Sweden`s kids? Sweden`s intelligence service are under fire after a James Bond-themed party, And SAAB`s former owner are set to team up with the Chinese company that weren`t allowed to buy the Swedish carmaker. All that and more in today`s programme from Radio Sweden!
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 24th August 2012
item.description: Norwegian mass-murderer Anders Behring Breivik is convicted in an Oslo court, as Sweden and the world looks on. We hear about a new wave of holiday home buying in Turkey. And we speak to the man behind a film that is winning over both pundits and cinemagoers
item.itunes:summary: Norwegian mass-murderer Anders Behring Breivik is convicted in an Oslo court, as Sweden and the world looks on. We hear about a new wave of holiday home buying in Turkey. And we speak to the man behind a film that is winning over both pundits and cinemagoers
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: August 23, 2012
item.description: After threats, one local area has had to escort Somali children to school. A Colombian Swede is accused of being a terrorist, we talk to one of his supporters, who is giving evidence in the trial. Sexually transmitted diseases are on the rise in Sweden. There are new attempts to deal with one of the biggest problems in Swedish society - the social and economic segregation of certain areas of the country. Ever thought of buying a home in Sweden? Our reporter takes us through how and why people can get a tax deduction for their mortgage. Music: Accident and Emergency, Patrick Wolf. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Ann McNab Törnkvist.

item.title: 22nd August 2012
item.description: More people are being bullied at work in Sweden, and some would say the increase is down to the financial crisis The Julian Assange case has thrown the spotlight onto Swedish rape laws. Is it easier to convict someone for the crime here? There`s exactly a week to go to the paralympics in London, we look at Sweden`s medal chances And we find out more about pole dancing greens fighting global warming. Presenter: Dave Russell

item.title: August 20th 2012
item.description: We talk to a veteran Swedish journalist who claims the Swedish media is biast against Julian Assange It`s the first day back at school after the long summer holidays but for those children who suffered from classroom bullies last year, will this new term be any different? A summer project tries to inspire a new generation of female scientists - we hear from the girls themselves And we meet an art collective aiming to stop youngsters fleeing from rural communities..

item.title: August 17th 2012
item.description: We get a legal breakdown of Sweden`s position in the Assange situation. We speak to a Swedish supporter of Russian punk band Pussy Riot on why freedom of speech matters to Swedes. And a work of art is stopping passers by in Stockholm in their tracks and making them think about poverty. Presenter: Sophie Vukovic. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou

item.title: Radio Sweden 16th August 2012
item.description: Ecuador has granted Julian Assange asylum. Should Sweden bring in plain packages for cigarettes,like Australia has just done? The number of women suffering from one particular lung problem has increased dramatically. In a recent poll far fewer people say that tax dodging is ok, we talk to the head of the tax agency. We report on the situation with organised crime in the city of Södertälje after the major gang trial. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou. Producer: Ann McNabb Törnkvist.

item.title: August 15 2012
item.description: The government fails to raise allowances for asylum seekers for, and get this, 18 years. We hear about the life of a Swedish journalist working in the US. The Brazilian soccer legend Pele says goodbye to the Swedish stadium where he won the world cup. Data inspectors in Sweden want to meet with Facebook about some of its new features. Closing Music: "Jag kan fortfarande inte sova", by PH3 Host: Gabriel Stein

item.title: 14th August 2012
item.description: Yet another state agency letting tax payers pay the party tab. A Swedish police expert says Sweden would fare no better than Norway if a Breivik struck here. Politics, fashion, and the sartorial power to capture swing voters. TeliaSonera helps the Tajik regime censor the internet. Swedish teenagers fall asleep in science class. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Ulla Engberg. Music: "tappar" by Little Marbles.

item.title: 13th August 2012
item.description: Why did the Defence Minister refuse to call Saudi Arabia a dictatorship? Sweden`s performance at the Olympics - not too shabby, but worse than Norway. Is Roxette the ultimate Sweden advertisement? And Swedish suburbs fall into disrepair. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Ulla Engberg. Music: "I Follow Rivers" by Lykke Li.

item.title: August 10 2012
item.description: Swedish dairy farmers are having a tough time of it due to falling milk prices. Special tax zones in depressed areas, can they help create jobs? Our special Friday guest, Mattias Göransson, talks about the new book that he edited: "The case of Thomas Quick, to create a serial murderer". Closing Music: “Klockan är väl två”, by Monica Zetterlund

item.title: August 8th 2012
item.description: Outrage that government agency directors can keep their salary and benefits even after they get fired for doing a bad job. We talk to a Swedish soldier who three years after returning from Afghanistan is still suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. Ice cream you scream we all scream for ice cream. But how do they pick the flavors? Sweden`s Olympic equestrians thank their horses. Host: Gabriel Stein

item.title: August 7th 2012
item.description: The data retention law was supposed to help police investigate crimes, but now they say it`s not enough. The strong Swedish krona and the euro crisis has made Sweden more expensive for tourists. Reggae music --

item.title: 3rd August 2012
item.description: Islamophobes and pinkwashing. We speak with two LGBTQ refugees. A family welcomes underage asylum seekers in their home. Finally, bees and the city - the buzz about urban hives. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Sven Hultberg Carlsson. Song: "Honung" by Säkert!

item.title: 2nd August 2012
item.description: Pride is well underway here, and Sweden`s EU minister has a message for her European colleagues. A year after the Supreme Court softened its stance on some drug crimes, we look at the results and the reactions And yet more disappointment in the London Olympics, with that predicted final medal tally for Sweden sinking all the time...

item.title: 1st August 2012
item.description: Final verdicts in Sweden`s first mafia trial - life in prison for its leader. An alternative community south of Stockholm refuses to vaccinate its children against measles. The Christian Democrats, accused of supporting eugenics last year, are at Pride. Inflation rises, but travel card prices soar. And we speak to Sweden`s fist Olympics medalist. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Sven Hultberg Carlsson. Music: "haffa" by Ison & Fille..

item.title: 31st July 2012
item.description: A new drug is linked to 14 deaths and Swedish customs prepare to fight it. Teacher salary negotiations broke down earlier this summer - what happens now? It`s CSI for animals, as Swedish vets want to help bring abusers to court. And, the Swedish economy soars, while farmers turn to the stock market. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: George Wood. Music: Björn Afzelius` and Mikael Wiehe`s Swedish cover of Peggy Seeger`s "Song of Choice."

item.title: 30th July 2012
item.description: Afghan interpreters for the Swedish troops apply for asylum - we hear from the Migration Board and the Swedish forces. Then looking at migration from Somalia, we speak with teenager Mustafa. Pride kicks off in Stockholm but has it been hijacked by the leftwing? Finally, are Sweden`s Olympic Games outfits not Swedish enough? Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: George Wood. Music: "Call on me" by Eva Dahlgren.

item.title: 27th July 2012
item.description: Sweden`s EU-minister calls political developments in Romania "unacceptable". The wait is finally over as the Olympics officially open tonight, we take a look at the Swedish squad, and find out how things are going for poor swimmer Therese Alshammar. And then we meet the man behind Abba`s stage costumes.
item.itunes:summary: Sweden`s EU-minister calls political developments in Romania "unacceptable". The wait is finally over as the Olympics officially open tonight, we take a look at the Swedish squad, and find out how things are going for poor swimmer Therese Alshammar. And then we meet the man behind Abba`s stage costumes.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 26th July 2012
item.description: New figures indicate the Swedish economy is keeping out of recession, just. The Swedish authorities want to clamp down on noisy festivals, but what will it mean? And Sweden get off to a good start in the London Olympics. All that, and a whole lot more...

item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 25th July 2012
item.description: There`s a rift in the Swedish government over sanctions against Syria. The police wonder whether a series of fires in Ystad is the work of a copycat arsonist. Should the authorities have the right to say whether you`re religious enough? A rainy summer means drivers have to contend with the hazards that weeds create. Meet the French baker who wants to give Swedes that special ooh la la. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Ann McNab Törnkvist.

item.title: 24th July 2012
item.description: The Swedish Foreign Ministry and its personnel in Damascus can`t do much to help the Swedes in Syria. Over a half a century later, Dag Hammarskjöld`s death remains a mystery, but a new investigation aims to get to the bottom of what happened once and for all. Sweden`s HIV laws come under fire again. Counting down to the Olympics, we speak to one Swedish hopeful about who`s more important: horse or rider? And we round up with a galactic chat about where Sweden`s space program is today. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Sven Hultberg Carlsson.

item.title: 23rd July 2012
item.description: Another blow to Swedish Olympic hopes as Carolina Klüft pulls out of the Games. Studying in Stockholm may be one thing, but having a roof over your head is another - will students resort to drastic measures for housing? Could the next big tourist craze here be reindeer milk? And he`s set to play table tennis at the Olympics for the seventh time in a row: Swedish star athlete Jörgen Persson talks to us about what drives him. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Sven Hultberg Carlsson.

item.description: Sweden looks back at last July`s terror attacks in neighbouring Norway. We ask why so many Swedes are filing for personal bankruptcy? We hear from teenage boys who want to defy the so called "macho myth". And we meet the man responsible for Sweden`s Eurovision victory. Presenter: Sophie Vukovic Producer: Sven Hultberg Carlsson Music: "Heaven is Burning" by The Radio Dept

What`s the deal with gambling - is the government controlling it for the right reasons? Ramadan starts tomorrow, and we ask how you can fast when the sun barely sets? And, as the Olympics near, the Swedish soccer team gears up to face its toughest competitor. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Sven Hultberg Carlsson

And pesky mosquitoes, plus expensive cancer treatments. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Kris Boswell. Music: "Skymtar för en stund" with Sara Isaksson and Martin Östergren.

Swedish culture fails to keep up with millions of one-person households. And a Swedish wrestler warms up for the Olympics. Presente: Ann McNab Törnkvis. Producer: Kris Boswell. item.description: A Swedish-American family wins on a technicality after Swedish law prevented them from dividing their dead daughter`s ashes. During renovations of the Stockholm underground, biologists find more than they bargained for. The Gothia Cup kicks off, the serial killer trial is wrapping up in Malmö, and Swedish reactions to the Libor scandal. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Kris Boswell.

item.title: July 13th 2012
item.description: The government says newly arrived immigrants can get paid to both work and study Swedish at the same time. Could Sweden`s most popular athlete be on the move, again? And our Friday guests, Kaiser Mahmood, talks about his book, and the journey he took to discover what it means to be Swedish. Host: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: “Fredag hela månaden” by Afasi and Filthy

A Swedish trade agency gets charged with the tough task of standardizing clothing sizes throughout Europe. And what happens when selling stuff on the Swedish version of eBay goes wrong? Host: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: The Embassy, “It pays to belong”

item.title: Radio Sweden 28th June 2012
item.description: The Green Party finally pushes the government to give medical care to illegal immigrants, setting a standard, it says, for Europe. Bad news for Stephen Colbert, he might be tweeting about tweeting for Sweden but his lazy tweeting habits have scuppered his ambition. Following on to parliament`s controversial suggestion on how to fight hooliganism, which just got the red card. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Kris Boswell.

item.title: Radio Sweden 27th June 2012
item.description: The prime minister is in Brussels, fighting Sweden`s corner in the debate about a tighter and more centrally controlled European Union. This morning, Swedish Radio reported that Sweden is considered the only western democracy still deporting members of the ethnic Weegur minority to China. Closer to home, we may not have any sunshine yet, but the options for street food if you dare leave your house may cheer you up some. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Tom Sullivan. Music: "Skisser för sommaren" by Kent.

item.title: Radio Sweden 26th June 2012
item.description: The Foreign Minister and his European colleagues are discussing Montenegro`s entry to the European Union. Is it just way of stalling the process? On the domestic front, the Green Party accuses the government of covering up the real price of nuclear energy. All while the capital Stockholm battles it out with southern city Malmö to host next year`s Eurovision Song Contest. Presenter Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Gabriel Stein. Music: "Little Brother" by The Tallest Man on Earth.

item.title: Radio Sweden 25th June 2012
item.description: Are the police too slow when investigating accidents at work...? Evidence can disappear, and when the employers aren`t Swedish, looking for the bad guy is even harder, says a union. Scientists in Gothenburg and Oslo have found a hormone that makes people better at interpreting other people`s feelings, can it be used to make people feel better? The annual summer holidays have begun in Sweden, but will families be able to afford it this year?And once you survive the summer, look ahead, to the health of the Swedish pension system. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Music: "Save the World" by the Swedish House Mafia.

item.description: A special programme for the Midsummer holiday. Radio Sweden`s Dave Russel talks to Natalia Brzezinski, wife of the US ambassador to Sweden, Mark Brzezinski. A former freelance journalist and figure skater, Chicago born Natalia Brzezinski talks about her work in promoting women`s rights and empowerment in Sweden as well as the struggle to maintain a balance between work and family.

item.title: Radio Sweden 7th June 2012
item.description: ---BSK: Sweden is taking in and burning other countries` rubbish - what does this mean for Europe`s move to more recycling? And does it affect local health? We talk to one of the top people at the Environmental Protection Agency. We hear about a possible break-through on Alzheimers medicine. Then a professional Swedish skateboarder speaks out. Discussions in Sweden on new ways to save more people from sea disasters. And it was Sweden`s National Day yesterday. Thousands have become new citizens. But we talk to a politician who says that Swedishness needs to be redefined, to make it accessible for immigrants. Presenter: Loukas Christodulou. Producer: Tom Sullivan.

item.title: Radio Sweden 6th June 2012
item.description: A special outside broadcast, live from Medborgarplatsen in central Stockholm, with the focus on Sweden and sports. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.
item.itunes:summary: A special outside broadcast, live from Medborgarplatsen in central Stockholm, with the focus on Sweden and sports. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: 5th June 2012
item.description: A look at how the EU crisis affects Sweden Environmental group says Sweden can go totally green by 2030 Is the Swedish media censoring itself on Islamic terrorism? Presenter: Tom Sullivan Music: Sean Banan, "Sommar i Sverige"
item.itunes:summary: A look at how the EU crisis affects Sweden Environmental group says Sweden can go totally green by 2030 Is the Swedish media censoring itself on Islamic terrorism? Presenter: Tom Sullivan Music: Sean Banan, "Sommar i Sverige"

item.title: 4th June 2012
item.description: Four men with Swedish ties are found guilty of plotting a terrorism attack against a newspaper in Denmark. We have the story. Is the plastic liner in tin cans harmful? We make a rare visit to where Sweden carries out its radio and signals intelligence. And what`s it like to run a marathon during the coldest June weekend in 84 years?
item.itunes:summary: Four men with Swedish ties are found guilty of plotting a terrorism attack against a newspaper in Denmark. We have the story. Is the plastic liner in tin cans harmful? We make a rare visit to where Sweden carries out its radio and signals intelligence. And what`s it like to run a marathon during the coldest June weekend in 84 years?
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: 1st June 2012
item.description: What`s at the bottom of more than 200 cases of narcolepsy after the swine flu scare? We`ll find out why building a bypass around Stockholm is so controversial. As the Olympics approaches, a couple of Sweden`s athletes tell us about their goals. And one of Sweden`s best-known sportsmen retires from a stellar hockey career in the States. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: 30th May 2012
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange loses his appeal at the Supreme Court in London against his extradition to Sweden to face sex crime allegations. However, the legal saga drags on ..We`ve all the reaction and analysis from today`s hearing in London Also in the programme, We meet a disabled Swedish army veteran from Afghanistan And we ask are Swedish strawberries the best in the world
item.itunes:summary: The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange loses his appeal at the Supreme Court in London against his extradition to Sweden to face sex crime allegations. item.title: Radio Sweden 28th May 2012
item.description: The spies from dictatorships abroad that are tracking their opponents here in Sweden... We hear claims of how Swedish health clinics shorten waiting times by cheating And there`s Euphoria as Sweden wins the Eurovision Song Contest
item.itunes:summary: The spies from dictatorships abroad that are tracking their opponents here in Sweden... We hear claims of how Swedish health clinics shorten waiting times by cheating And there`s Euphoria as Sweden wins the Eurovision Song Contest

item.title: Radio Sweden 25 May 2012
item.description: A court rules that the teaching profession can be compared that of the police and, that a little violence goes with the job. Two of Sweden's most well-known regional airlines went bust this week, we find out what's on the horizon for the country's aviation industry. Sweden has one of the highest rates of skin cancer in Europe, but on one of the hottest days of the year so far, are Swedes slapping on the sunscreen or not?
item.itunes:summary: A court rules that the teaching profession can be compared that of the police and, that a little violence goes with the job. Sweden has one of the highest rates of skin cancer in Europe, but on one of the hottest days of the year so far, are Swedes slapping on the sunscreen or not?

item.title: Radio Sweden 24 May 2012
item.description: Amnesty International has released its annual report and top of the list when it comes to Sweden`s offences is sending people back to Iraq. As a mob of 60 teenagers pelt the police with stones and set a school alight in a Stockholm suburb, commentators ask, is it due to social exclusion? Or are we just talking about kids acting up? And while the police try to keep things calm at home, Swedish peacekeepers abroad get a bit more attention in a new book. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist Producer: Tom Sullivan
item.itunes:summary: Amnesty International has released its annual report and top of the list when it comes to Sweden`s offences is sending people back to Iraq. And while the police try to keep things calm at home, Swedish peacekeepers abroad get a bit more attention in a new book. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist Producer: Tom Sullivan

item.title: Radio Sweden 23 May 2012
item.description: A date has been set for the British Supreme Court`s judgement on Julian Assange`s possible extradition to Sweden. Ahead of the EU crisis meeting in Brussels, Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt is highly critical against the idea of Eurobonds. After the TeliaSonera affair in Belarus - the government demands that state-owend companies take their social responsibility seriously. It was supposed to make it easier to recruit people abroad, but the new rules on immigrant workers seem to attract mainly short-term workers. We meet a British expat, who set up the The English Volunteering Project Music: The Embassy "It never entered my mind" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 22 May 2012
item.description: Today saw the baptism of a little princess, and people gathered around the castle to celebrate. Elsewhere in Sweden, people turned up at airports only to find out that the regional airline Skyways will no longer fly. After the Chicago summit - Sweden is one step closer to Nato. And in Malmö, on the second week of the trial against the suspected serial shooter, we talk to residents who say that if he is found guilty, it`s time to stop making excuses for his crimes. Music: Bo Kaspers Orkester "Satsa några kronor på mig" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Radio Sweden 21 May 2012
item.description: Sweden`s once renowned social safety net has gotten thinner. And a political analyst says the change in the country`s unemployment benefit may be here to stay. There`s a lack of diversity in the leadership of Sweden`s biggest popular movement - sports. It`s almost time for 3-month-old Princess Estelle to get christened. We look at how Sweden is spinning tomorrow`s big event. And the art scene rewinds to 1971 to find out what a little flower power might cure these days.. Music: Lasse Tenander Livet, Musiken och konsten att stämma en gitarr. Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Radio Sweden May 18th 2012
item.description: Seventy-five unaccompanied minors have disappeared from asylum centers in Sweden this year. If you`re young and doing temporary summer work, where you live, will have a major impact on how much you make per hour. The Egyptian human rights activist Nawal El Saadawi wins a prestigious Swedish prize. We talk with Anton Hysén, the professional Swedish soccer player who made big news when he came out of the closet. Closing Music: Sara Dawn Finer, "I`ll be your wish tonight" Presenter: Gabriel Stein

item.title: Radio Sweden May 16th 2012
item.description: As the Supreme Court hears a child pornography case based on Japanese cartoons, we hear about the debate the case has sparked off. And speaking about debates, Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt`s statements about "ethnic Swedes" has become a major talking point, we`ll tell you why. Swedish companies` carbon emissions dropped last year, but you may be surprised by the reason. And we hear from the winners of the young entrepreneur contests. It`s all about hockey sticks. Presenter: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Christian Kjellvander, “Homeward Rolling Soldier”

item.title: Radio Sweden 11th May 2012
item.description: The high profile bribery and corruption case against six people involved in the building of Sweden`s National Football Arena reaches its verdict Lundin Oil`s stakeholders vote against reviewing its operations in Sudan and Ethiopia And with the European song contest just a couple of weeks away, there`s a call for host nation Azerbajan to ease up on human rights violations And in our Friday interview we look at plans for Sweden`s first Music Hall of Fame

item.title: Radio Sweden 10th May 2012
item.description: ---BSK: A Swedish study casts doubt on the validity of ADHD diagnoses - A doctor suggests that many children with ADHD may simply be too young for school After the long winter, thousands of Swedes choose to cycle to work but with nearly half of all serious traffic related injuries involving a cyclist, how can their safety be ensured? We speak to the politician that`s peddling Denmark`s cycling experience as a roadmap for Swedes And climate certified beef, is it really climate friendly or just a lot of hot air? Presenter Dave Russell

item.title: Radio Sweden May 9th 2012
item.description: What`s being described as Sweden`s largest criminal gang case ever is wrapping up today in Sodertalje. And Police say the criminal investigation isn`t over. We learn more about the alleged serial shooter in Malmö. The Swedish language can be a problem for foreigners who are recruited here for work. Pharmacies in rural areas are under threat. We talk about the Swedish film industry, the challenges ahead. Presenter: Gabriel Stein

item.description: The antibiotic-resistant bacteria keeps spreading with no end in sight. Can we understand what officials are talking about? A clash of cultures emerges as thousands of Swedes plan to visit Ukraine for the European football championsips. Camping is a boom industry here. And the Polar Music prize is announced --

item.description: The prosecution presents its case against Malmö`s suspected serial shooter. The first televised party leader debate since Stefan Löfven took over the Social Democrats. Latest from the Ice Hockey World Championships in Stockholm. Finland wants more Finnish-language care homes to cater for elderly Finns in Sweden Frog tunnels to be built in Stockholm to save love-sick frogs from being run over by cars. Music: The Deportees The Doctor in Me

item.description: The Panther project on gang culture.. Swedes are giving more to charity And did you know it`s international Star Wars day And in our in depth friday interview we`re joined by Sweden`s national football coach Erik Hamren, looking ahead to this summer`s European Football championships

item.title: Radio Sweden May 3rd 2012
item.description: Greenpeace boards a ship docked in Sweden that’s heading to the Arctic for oil exploration. The Social Democrats release their shadow spring budget. A new survey suggests that the Green Party has taken over as the favored party of journalists. And what happened when bee researchers from England came here to take home 100 queen bees? Researchers say this may be the worst year for pollen in a decade. Presenter: Gabriel Stein

item.title: Radio Sweden May 2nd 2012
item.description: It`s a week today since a young woman was stabbed to death in her apartment in a suspected honor killing. A protest is planned tonight in Malmö. And Sweden is promoting snuff or snus outside of the country. We talk to a Green Party politician who wants to stop it. A serious strain of Group A streptococcus bacteria has broken out in the south of Sweden. A growing number of people are hiding....on line. Presenter: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Frida Hyvönen, ”It gets terribly dark here”

item.title: Radio Sweden 30th April 2012
item.description: ---pod: The latest from the first and perhaps only trial in connection with the suicide attack in Stockholm in 2010. New proposal to increase the efforts to stop violent men from importing wives from abroad - again and again. Saving the sound of summer - How bee conservationists in the UK have stung Swedish environmentalists. And.. It`s bonfire time in Sweden Music: Frida Hyvönen Jesus was a cross maker Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Radio Sweden 26th April 2012
item.description: Sweden takes stock of what even the justice minister is calling a failure after a young woman`s life was cut short by what appears to be an honor killing. Then, we`ll look at possible changes to online gambling here in Sweden. It`s been 50 years since Sweden pulled a dangerous drug from the shelves. We speak to one of the so-called children of thalidomide, now grown up. And finally, are berries good for your brain? Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Dave Russell.

We speak to one of the so-called children of thalidomide, now grown up. And finally, are berries good for your brain? Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Dave Russell.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 25 April 2012
item.description: The Chinese premier continues his visit. As usual, people protest the country`s presence. But the main focus is on trade and environmental cooperation. Wen Jiabo spoke at a green conference in Stockholm this week. And while Sweden may be selling green tech to China, many more Swedes are selling their own skills on the Chinese job market despite cultural barriers. Also, why kids are bored to death in the Stockholm archipelago while waiting for summer. And what the near-by capital`s premier amusement park is offering to combat the blues. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Gabriel Stein. Music: "Beredda på allt" by Kent.

item.title: Radio Sweden 24 April 2012
item.description: Split work shifts play havoc with some employees` private lives Another Lundin company finds itself in hot water over its activities in Africa, this time it`s Lundin Mining in Congo. We visit one of the new fancy coffee shops sprouting up all over town. And if you get your kicks from nicotine, rather than coffee, today you`ll learn where the smoke-free, snuff habit snus originally came from. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist. Producer: Gabriel Stein. Music: `Tack för kaffet` by Timbuktu and Dregen.

item.description: What the Chinese prime minister`s visit means for Sweden, and what Swedish cars and green technology mean for China. How small bats are putting a big spanner in the works for wind power. And how the EU is once again threatening the most Swedish tobacco of them all... Snus. Presenter: Ann McNab Törnkvist Music: "Distant and Dreamy" by Sahara Hotnights

item.title: Radio Sweden April 20th, 2010
item.description: The party secretary for the conservative Moderate party Sofia Arkelsten has resigned Investing in infrastructure is expensive and takes time. How does that sit with the Swedish government`s efforts to stabilize the economy We talk to Artist Makonde Linde, the man behind the cake of a naked African woman that has drawn headlines this week. And As computers and ipads become more common in classrooms more and more children are learning to read and write without a pencil and paper. Presenter: Cajsa Collin, Producer: Ann Törnkvist, Closing Music: Ulf Lundell "Rom i Regnet"

item.title: Radio Sweden 16 April
item.description: We look at the pros and cons of the government`s spring budget which was presented today.. Also the thoughts of Sweden`s unemployed on the news that the country`s national employment service gave back nearly 2 and a half billion dollars of unspent money, despite high youth unemployment... We cross over to Oslo for the opening day of Norway`s trial of the century which has reverberated not just here in neighbouring sweden but all around the world And every man for himself, the Swedish researcher who found that the classic women and children first on board the titanic is more myth than reality...

item.title: Radio Sweden April 11th, 2012
item.description: Why one of Sweden's heaviest hitting unions is threatening a national strike. Sweden may copy English legislation to crack down on football hooligans. We head to Gävle for a dose of ice hockey. And somewhere between all these star athletes, we ask, "Is aiming for that dream job still possible on today`s labour market?"

item.title: Radio Sweden April 10th, 2012
item.description: Today`s the last day for companies to bid for the bankrupt iconic Swedish car brand Saab. We talk to a former Saab employee. Critics blast courts for denying lawyers to people charged with minor offenses. Sweden`s cities are booming, but that means growing pains. A Swedish web company`s not that popular with dictatorships these days. The lawless industry of plastic surgery. Music: Molotov Jive, "Song for the Fallen Apart" Presenter: Gabriel Stein.

item.title: Radio Sweden April 4th 2012
item.description: In today`s half hour of Swedish news and views in English. The Swedish sex law which is penalising teenagers. Another big theft of copper from a popular rail route brings more misery to train travellers. We ask how can it be stopped Also, Honour related crime, a new report slams police attitudes. In sport, we talk to the general manager of Sweden`s men`s handball team as they aim to qualify for the london olympics this weekend. And Happy Birthday Alfie Atkins, the Swedish 5-year-old who celebrates his 40th birthday this year.

item.title: Radio Sweden 30th March 2012
item.description: The Swedish Saudi weapons deal may have claimed its first victim, as the defense minister resigned yesterday. We spoke to the journalist who broke the story. Should Swedes be hungrier for genetically modified foods, or do they just cause more problems? We`ll find out why the national museum is on the move. And for our special Friday guest segment, we talk to a historian about a topic that`s on many Swedes lips: the housing shortage. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Gabriel Stein.

item.title: Radio Sweden 29th March 2012
item.description: Defence minister Sten Tolgfors has resigned Radio Sweden has all the details. More and more employers ask job applicants to provide a copy of their criminal records but how accurate are these documents really? The Swedish compulsory school is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year but what has time done to the quality of education in Sweden? The henerator allows you to replace all gender pronouns with a gender neutral option on all swedish websites, but how do people react to this invention. Presenter: Cajsa Collin. Producer: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: Radio Sweden 23rd March 2012
item.description: Large banks and pension funds are putting major pressure on the oil company Lundin Petroleum over it`s work in Sudan. Sweden`s children`s ombudsman says that social services are not prioritizing investigation into child sex abuse. The Arctic is becoming a hotspot for possible oil finds, and new trade routes. How is Sweden doing, as chair of the Arctic Council? And following the recent shooting at a French Jewish school, this Friday`s in-depth interview is with the rabbi of Stockholm`s biggest synagogue. Does he feel under threat? Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden 22nd March 2012
item.description: Today is a week since a Norwegian plane crashed in Sweden`s north. We hear from the man in charge of the search operation. Workers at a major clothing company say they`re being bullied. One of them speaks anonymously to us. We join archaeologists searching for the vanished bones of one of Sweden`s medieval kings. And never mind groundhogs - it`s bears on the loose that are a sign of Sweden`s early spring. All of that`s coming up, after we hear the latest updates and the weather, from the news desk. Music: Roxette, `It`s possible`. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

Then, a debate in education: Should six-year-olds have to take reading tests? And what`s on the menu as a Swedish chef vies to win the European championship of cooking? Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Gabriel Stein."

Swedish skiier Anja Persson`s last race. And painting the town green. Stockholm gets ready for St. Patrick`s Day tomorrow.

item.title: Radio Sweden 15th March 2012
item.description: Parliament refuses to fast track an investigation into a Swedish Saudi weapons factory deal. Save the Children responds to criticism from the Prime Minister about their new report that shows child poverty on the rise. As the possibility of a pardon still seems alive, Kjell Persson talks to us about how he`s coping - his son is a journalist in jail in Ethiopia for supporting terrorism. Can Systembolaget`s code of ethics help bring social justice to vineyards worldwide? And we at the Swedish market for computer games.

item.description: One of the new private landlords defend the much criticised sale of thousands apartments in Stockholm. We hear about tomorrow`s Melodifestivalen final, with analysis in the studio. Music: Loreen `Euphoria.` Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden 1st March 2012
item.description: We have a Radio Sweden exclusive - speaking to the Belgian politician who says the two Swedes in Ethiopia will soon be pardoned. And we put questions to the government minister who`s had to retreat in the face of parliament`s opposition on sick pay. One of our reporters followed the trash trail, seeing what happens to the average Swede`s 16 kilos of electrical waste. Then we go to Tensta, to find out why this area is the site of one of the world`s top art galleries. And a report on the victory of the Swedish football team last night. Music: Timbuktu, Flickan och kråkan. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.description: The international body that regulates nuclear power announces the result of its inspection over here. The Friday interview - Fredrick Gertten on his follow-up film after Bananas - now it`s about his battle with fruit company Dole. Music: Thåström "Beväpna Dig Med Vingar". Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden 16th February 2012
item.description: Sweden`s interest rate cut - will it make mortgages cheaper? Sweden is the country that makes the most complaints to the EU. We talk to someone from the snowmobile association about what can be done to improve safety. Sweden will soon carry out its first face transplant. Three places in Sweden now offer drop-in times, for parents who want to pop in and get their child baptised. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden 15th February 2012
item.description: This morning, parliament sunk its teeth into several contentious foreign policy issues. We speak with the foreign minister, Carl Bildt. Then we take a look at how Swedish companies behave in China, and further afield how shooting blood into space can help us on earth. We`ll get a proper update from the stars and the champagne of last night`s Grammy Awards, and as artists party, scientists keep a close eye on the Nobel Prize and ask if it`s too entangled with its corporate sponsors.

item.title: Radio Sweden 14th February 2012
item.description: The number of people stuck outside the labour market for a longer period of time is on the rise. We speak with a person who's spent the past three years looking for work. And then a sociologist tells us how unemployment in your early 20's can come to haunt you. And if all that's too depressing for you on this Valentine`s Day, we hear from Swedish kids about love, and how it`s not just reserved for their peers. Then onto why Swedes and their families pay half of the taxes on carbon emissions, even though companies produce 80 percent of the pollution.

item.title: Radio Sweden 13th February 2012
item.description: Children developed narcolepsy after a vaccine against swine flu: Parents want life-long support for their sick children. The head of the Infectious Diseases Institute explains why they feared swine flu so much at the time. The "Dawn Arsonist" now behind bars - why`d it take so long to catch him? The Aid Minister wants "less talking, more action" in development cooperation, her critics say she`s "fixated" on short-term goals.

item.title: Radio Sweden 10th February 2012
item.description: When doctors make mistakes, red tape is getting in the way of revoking their licenses. Then, our Friday in-depth interview focuses on the Swedish hero who saved thousands of people during WW2, Raoul Wallenberg. We meet his sister, Nina Lagergren. Swedish authorities warn skiiers of avalanches. And a new exhibition in Stockholm looks at how film and art inspire one another.

item.title: Radio Sweden 9th February 2011
item.description: European Court of Human Rights upholds the Swedish Supreme Court`s criminal conviction of four men for distributing leaflets offensive to homosexuals. Nine prime ministers from Scandinavia, the Baltics and Britain assemble in Stockholm to discuss future challenges to sustainable growth. One feminist author explains what it means to be politically depressed. And we learn about one big cause of train delays: copper theft!

A new report reveals large shortfalls in protection against corruption. The Swedish golfer who bags not one but two, holes in one

item.title: Radio Sweden 7th February 2012
item.description: Reaction to the prime minister`s idea that Swedes should consider retiring at 75 years of age.. There`s an alarming jump in mental illness in teenage girls There`s a call for tighter rules to catch the hackers attacking Swedish websites While the Netherlands decision to ban the drug Khat is welcomed by customs officers here And we meet a volleyball coach whose only the second woman in Swedish history to train men in the elite series of any sport.

item.title: Radio Sweden February 2nd 2012
item.description: Police try to deal with a rise in deadly crime in Malmo. The pharmaceutical company Astra Zeneca is cutting over a thousand jobs. Sweden`s overseas aid minister says to Radio Sweden that other countries aren`t as committed as Sweden to fighting poverty internationally. We speak to someone at an outreach centre who says that more Swedish men are contacting them, asking for help to stop buying sex. And more men than ever are taking paternity leave here, what does it mean for the family and society?

item.description: Analysis and reaction to Sweden`s decision to join the EU pact How new technology brought in to prevent prison escapes is unworkable Following the tragic death of a young Swedish snowboarder at the weekend, we ask just how safe is the sport? And find out how Swedish researchers claim that dogs can help in the battle against lung cancer. We hope you enjoy the podcast

item.title: Radio Sweden 26th January 2012
item.description: The ailing Social Democrat party goes back to its root by turning to a metal union heavyweight for leadership. While Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt stepped out of the media shadow and yesterday took questions directly from the public on air. And as holocaust remembrance day is honoured in Sweden by the royal family and a visiting Kofi Annan, we speak with a woman who survived the genocide and later moved to Sweden with her sister. Job prospects are tough, especially for the young, unless you have special competence, or are prepared to head to the north.

item.title: Radio Sweden 25th January 2012
item.description: A government reform aimed at helping asylum-seekers get off to a good start in Sweden is having the opposite effect. We hear how tumbling profits for Swedish telecom giant Ericsson aren`t just a problem for the company itself. Exactly a year after the revolution started in Cairo, we talk to a young Egyptian in Sweden who stood in Tahrir Square when it all began. Fans of the Swedish carmaker heave a sigh of relief now that the Saab Car Museum is being saved from the auction block. We look at the Swedish nominations for the Oscars. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: Radio Sweden 16 January 2012
item.description: How will Sweden fund future healthcare for an increasingly ageing population? Joining forces to defend the Nordic nations – we hear from the head of the Swedish military on one way to handle budget cutbacks. Demonstrators take to the streets calling for foreign minister, Carl Bildt to resign…And the battle rages on over the forced sterilization of people applying for sex changed in Sweden. Presenter: Tom Sullivan

item.title: Radio Sweden 13th January 2012
item.description: Weekly roundup: We speak with the Left Party`s newly elected leader Jonas Sjöstedt. The Health and Welfare Board says there are 4,000 more homeless people now than in 2005. How the debate over privately run but state financed elderly care is continuing into 2012. We also speak with Anne Skånér, who was abused as a child and now heads up "Society`s Stepchildren". Plus an interview with Joachim Östlund, a history researcher, about Sweden`s role in the slave trade. And finally: last year Ericsson and Sony broke up, meaning that there are now no Ericsson telephones on the market for the first time in over 130 years.

Plus an interview with Joachim Östlund, a history researcher, about Sweden`s role in the slave trade. And finally: last year Ericsson and Sony broke up, meaning that there are now no Ericsson telephones on the market for the first time in over 130 years.

item.description: Quick to give drugs, less quick to follow up - a new study into ADHD is critical. One third of Swedes want to scrap the monarchy, and 500 today told the government so. A new television deal reveals two unlikely bed fellows - commercial Swedish channel TV4 and the BBC. Paul came to Sweden for love, now he`s forced to sleep on a bench - and tweets about to raise awareness of homelessness. Presenter: Ann Törnkvist Music: Welcome to My Hell by The Go Getters

item.description: The Left Party has elected its new leader. We`ll fill you in on what this could mean for the party. After growing up in foster care homes, more and more Swedes are going back to dig up their records and find out what happened then. One municipality stops the construction of waterfront apartments, citing the environment. Sweden`s aging population presents challenges for coming generations. We interview the researcher who discovered that Sweden`s role in the slave trade went beyond just the transAtlantic route. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: MultiTrack -> Namnlös SRI 89.6 Engelska Repris
item.description: Three men arrested on suspicion of terrorism, then charged with conspiracy to murder, but now set free before the verdict is announced... What`s going on in Gothenburg? There may be no sun, but the future is bright for Kiruna. The mining town is riding high on iron and copper demand from emerging markets. Wanna learn Swedish? Sure, but it may take a while. Many municipalities aren`t fast enough in offering the state-funded courses. An EU ruling may affect how Sweden limits study grants and loans to those who want to go abroad. Music: Min pojke och Manhattan by Kajsa Grytt. Presenter: Ann Törnkvist
item.itunes:summary: Three men arrested on suspicion of terrorism, then charged with conspiracy to murder, but now set free before the verdict is announced... What`s going on in Gothenburg? There may be no sun, but the future is bright for Kiruna. The mining town is riding high on iron and copper demand from emerging markets. Wanna learn Swedish? Sure, but it may take a while. Many municipalities aren`t fast enough in offering the state-funded courses. An EU ruling may affect how Sweden limits study grants and loans to those who want to go abroad. Music: Min pojke och Manhattan by Kajsa Grytt. Presenter: Ann Törnkvist
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 28th December 2011
item.description: Former Social Democrat leader Mona Sahlin wants to let the Swedish people get to know the candidates for party leader. Not all colleagues agree. How to save construction workers from accidents? Communicate in their own language, of course. Why does Stockholm lag behind other Swedish cities when it comes to recycling food waste into biogas? And finally, why is it so warm... and where is the snow? We speak with the Met office. Presenter: Ann Törnkvist Music: Ibland Gör Man Rätt Ibland Gör Man Fel by Markus Krunegård

item.title: Radio Sweden 27th December 2011
item.description: Thousands are still without electricity due to storm Dagmar. The two Swedish journalists arrested in Ethiopia have been sentenced to eleven years, we hear from the Foreign Ministry. And we get the reaction on another sentence - in Sweden - against a man who paid for sex with children abroad, and hear about the general problem of Swedish sex tourism. Then we hear how the Swedish tradition of having judges nominated by political parties is coming under fire. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

Then we hear how the Swedish tradition of having judges nominated by political parties is coming under fire. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden December 23rd, 2011
item.description: The next steps for the two journalists found guilty of terrorism in Ethiopia. A Swedish parliamentarian wants the EU to investigate the Ogaden region of Ethiopia. Wind energy in Sweden has had a breakout year. How has the Christmas tradition changed here? Presenter: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Lars Vegas Trio, ”Sjömansjul På Hawaii”

item.description: We hear reaction to the sentence in Ethiopia against two Swedish journalists from foreign minister Carl Bildt. We talk to the first of many to give a very personal view of Sweden on this country`s official Twitter account. Christmas isn`t such a big celebration for the shops this year, with many buying online instead. The people who are supposed to inspect Sweden`s ferries have been enjoying too much cruise hospitality. Music: Avicii Vs Kings of Leon, "Levels on fire". Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden 21st December 2011
item.description: Frustrated and disappointed is the mood in Sweden today, as a long awaited judgment came from Ethiopia, convicting two Swedes of supporting terrorism. We focus on this in today`s edition of Radio Sweden and talk to a close colleague of the reporters, plus the head of the Swedish Journalists Federation... And, what happens when your small town doesn`t have enough workers? Try attracting them from the `burbs. The OECD criticizes Sweden`s labor migration policies. And finally, Christmastime eats up a lot of electricity, and lights turn out to be the biggest culprit. Presenters: Brett Ascarelli and Tom Sullivan.

item.title: Radio Sweden 19th December 2011
item.description: After a relentless 2-year roller coaster ride to survive, Saab has filed for bankruptcy. We`ll hear one employee’s reaction, and bring you the latest details and analysis on what’s happened and what it means. What does the North Korean transition mean for Sweden? Butter crime on the Swedish and Norwegian border. Presenter: Gabriel Stein Closing Music: Håkan Hellström, ”En Vän Med En Bil”

Why did heavily armed police storm four homes last year, an act that led to nothing but scaring kids? We follow up on why the wrong children might be getting sent to special needs schools. We visit an exhibit about Afghanistan. And we find out what Swedes are looking for when they seek answers online...

item.title: Radio Sweden 9 December 2011
item.description: The Swedish government announces plans to combat extremism While we look ahead to potential violent clashes in Stockholm on Saturday as right wing extremists march through the old town And while all that`s going on, the nobel laureates are in town to pick up their awards and sit down to a sumptious nobel feast - We`ve gone behind the scenes in the kitchens and banquet hall to dish up a treat in our Friday feature Also, news of a major shock in the world of Swedish archaeology

item.title: Radio Sweden 1st December 2011
item.description: Two of Sweden`s leading politicians clash over environmenal issues We`re at Sweden`s military headquarters to hear how the top brass is going to keep the troops safe for the final phase of their Nato-led mission in Afghanistan. We report from Sweden`s second biggest city of gothenburg where there`s anger over school closures We`ve the historical picture of the Swedish landscape painter Carl Fredrik Hill And we meet some of Sweden`s young heroes of the year, one of whom was attacked by a bear. Enjoy the programme!

item.title: Radio Sweden 30 November 2011
item.description: The judgement in the trial of an emergency telephone operator accused of causing the death of a 23-year-old man by not sending an ambulance in response to his distress call. Sweden`s Education Minister presents his plans to reform the school marking system While pupils with a foreign background are struggling to get the grades to go to high school We`ve the details of a new project to help orphaned children from abroad settle in Sweden We discover that the art market here is booming despite the economic gloom.

item.title: Radio Sweden 29th November 2011
item.description: Despite economic gloom, figures still show strong Swedish growth. The man who`s proud of killing 77 people in Norway in July has been declared insane - we hear from a survivor. Sweden`s infrastructure minister says that it may be time to bring in laws, to force truck drivers to put on better winter tyres. We investigate a very popular series of philosophy lectures, and ask why are the no-nonsense Swedes flocking in their drives? Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden 25th November 2011
item.description: Should Swedish telecom giant Ericsson be supplying the Syrian regime with technology? We hear voices for and against. As the Sweden Democrats kick off their congress, there`s a proposal to soften the party`s label from nationalist to socially conservative. We have analysis. Our Friday guests sound off on Sweden`s presence in Afghanistan. And, goodbye mortar, hello frosting! Gingerbread houses compete at the Architecture Museum in the nation`s capital.

Closing Music: The Tallest Man on Earth, The Wild Hunt Presenter: Gabriel Stein

Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

Chemical fertilizer use on the rise in Swedish forests. Closing Music: Max Gustafsson, “Awake Nu”. Presenter: Gabriel Stein
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 1st November 2011
item.description: The trial against two Swedish journalists accused of terrorist activities in Ethiopia gets underway again. Sweden was one of just a few countries yesterday voting against giving Palestine full membership to UNESCO. We have analysis. Starting today, Swedes will have to pay a different price for electricity depending on where they live. A new hotline is rolled out to help prevent people from committing crimes when their sexual fantasies can hurt others. Nordic Council opens its 63rd annual session. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: Radio Sweden October 31, 2011
item.description: It`s more common for parents to kidnap their children and take them out of Sweden. Bank stability fund is not really a fund, says Swedish audit agency. Hundreds of people granted asylum in Sweden have their names released on an anti-immigrant website. What`s the problem with the wolrd "politically correct"? Closing Music: Adam Tensta, "Scared of the Dark". Presenter: Gabriel Stein

item.title: Radio Sweden 28th October 2011
item.description: Chinese companies have reportedly struck a deal to take over Saab completely. Thailand may be a popular hotspot for Swedes, but how are they coping with the massive flooding? Police get criticized for assuming some deaths are just accidents, when they could be murders instead. And our Friday guest talks to Radio Sweden about the state of the Internet and Sweden`s role in it. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: Radio Sweden 27th October 2011
item.description: We`ll have the latest reactions and actions from Sweden about the eurozone crisis. Will the new deal reached last night hurt Swedish banks? And we`ll hear about how the euro crisis is steering Sweden`s interest rates. An end of an era, as Swedish telecom Ericsson sells off its cell phone brand. We talk to a Swedish philosopher who says it is human to live without the net. Migration between countries is on the rise. Can Sweden keep up? Closing Music: ”Mediakåt”, by Helt Off. Presenter: Gabriel Stein

And we take a look back at 4 decades of environmental activism.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-0902
item.description: We hear that the Swedish government parties are having a hard time uniting on their attitude towards a Palestinian state. Is now a good time to sell, or to buy, a home? item.description: Coming up in today’s programme How do you police the Internet and which opinions should be allowed? Several Swedish newspapers have stopped allowing comments on their websites because of racist and offensive remarks. The Polar Music Prize will be awarded at a ceremony tonight I speak to music journalist Håkan Steen about one of the winners: Patti Smith. And there is more music news for you today. Sweden has gotten its first record label focusing on signing children. And in the search for the perfect body a growing number of Swedes chose to partly or completely exclude carbs from their diets, but at what cost? Closing Music: "People have the power" by Patti Smith

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-08-29
item.description: ---pod: Eight years on: new light is shed on the murder of Foreign Minister Anna Lindh, as her killer has decided to talk. Why are only 3% of all pre-school teachers in Sweden men? Artificially produced meat - can that be the future? New research shows that when a doctor orders more exercise - it actually works. Music: Tove Styrke "High and low" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-26
item.description: Today you will have another chance to listen to our programme about the 25th anniversary of the Chernobyl catastrophe and its impact here in Sweden. You`ll hear from the Swede who`s been called "the engineer who alerted the world" about the disaster. A former schoolboy who was in Kiev, not far from the disaster when it happened, tells his story. What do Swedes find appealing about visiting the melted down reactor now? And find out how much radiation is still here in Sweden.

item.description: It`s boom time for Sweden`s temping agencies, but what does their growth mean for the so-called "Swedish Model"? The four parties in the centre-right government are negotiating hard ahead of the upcoming Autumn budget. Why are berry pickers crossing the border from Finland? And what are the chances of a Swede ending up on the podium in the World Athletics Championships?

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-23
item.description: ---pod: Seven months into the Government`s programme to help immigrant to jobs only a handful have been successful. Only four out of thirty university and collage cities in Sweden are able to guarantee students housing. Scientists are warning we may be running out of helium. Should we be worried? The problem of young people ending up using sex as a way of self-harm, is highlighted in Stockholm today. A look at what Swedish film has got in store for us this autumn. Music: Sara Varga "Spring för livet" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-22
item.description: On Libya: we talk to a Sweden-based opposition activist. Today is the start of school again for thousands of young Swedes and a new law forces local councils to get better at dealing with complaints from pupils and parents. Hundreds of bears are to be shot in Sweden over the next months - 21 killed already on Sunday. A find, possibly a massive sunken Swedish battleship from about 450 years ago, brings back memories of when Sweden was a military superpower. What does it mean for consumers here, when scores of adverts on Swedish television have clearly been dubbed from another language? Music: Little Dragon, `Ritual Union`. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-18
item.description: Crown Princess Victoria is pregnant, that`s good news for some of this country`s newspapers and magazines. There`s controversy over a deal to buy helicopters for the army. There will be no wolf hunts this year, but that doesn`t mean the wolf population in Sweden is safe. And could a drug based on marijuana be about to get approved for use here in Sweden?

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-17
item.description: Analysis of the government`s decision to scrap promised tax breaks in light of a weakened economy. After yesterday`s explosion at a construction site in Gothenburg, we ask why more people are getting hurt on the job. The contest for the Left party`s next leader heats up as one more candidate joins the race. A Swedish woman abroad leaves her baby outside for just a moment while she runs an errand – with unexpected consequences. And, Sif Ruud, a beloved and unique Swedish actress passes away. Music: Den Sista Jäntan, by Monica Zetterlund. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-16
item.description: Is the extreme weather being experienced by those living in the west of Sweden a sign of what`s to come every summer? We meet two of Swedish national radio`s top foreign correspondents and find out about their life in the firing line.. Annika Östberg, the Swede imprisoned for 28 years in the USA for her role in two murders there unveils her autobiography. And for the first time ever, digital music sales in Sweden have surpassed those of cd and vinyl...

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-15
item.description: As the blood continues to flow in Syria, what can the international community do? Sweden looks back at its efforts to support the Baltic states and their fight for independence twenty years ago. Flooding hits western Sweden, even knocking local radio off the air, And then what will be the national treasure of the year? There are some world-famous candidates.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-12
item.description: We follow up on the aftermath of yesterday’s occupation of the Libyan Embassy. Has Sweden openly renounced the Gadhafi regime or are they allowing Libyan diplomats loyal to the dictator to stay in the country? The number of fire-fighters has gone down steadily in the past couple of years. Authorities say that improved technology still allows quality of the service to be maintained, while the fire-fighters warn that lives are at stake. And we have a very special feature for you today; Brett Ascarelli will take you on a guided tour of the Venice Biennale

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-11
item.description: Protestors break into the Libyan embassy in Stockholm. An Egyptian prisoner is released now, 10 years after the CIA deported him from a Swedish airport in 2001. We talk to finance minister Anders Borg about Sweden in the face of continued concerns about the world economy. A new map-making project is underway, including pictures of Sweden`s dwindling glaciers. And when it comes to Sweden`s hallmark foods, like meatballs, herring and more, some say the country should be more proactive. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.
