item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-10
item.description: As Lars Ohly announced he`s stepping down, some in the Left Party are considering finding two people to take the helm, instead of just one. A year since the first Swedish pig was discovered to carry multi-resistant bacteria, hear about a new investigation aiming to find out how widespread the problem is. Committing the perfect crime gets even harder as the Swedish Social Insurance Agency cracks down on criminals with benefits. One meteorologist explains why it`s been hard to predict the weather this summer. And a month after Sweden`s new litter laws went into effect, are they making a difference? Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-09
item.description: The financial crisis could have a devastating effect on the Swedish pension system but experts aren’t too worried yet….. Left Party leader Lars Ohly has become the latest party leader to resign following the poor results in the 2010 elections. And Stockholm Fashion week is underway, we sent Bret Ascarelli there to report. Also, after a lot of toes and froes the queen has released her findings after looking into her family’s ties with the German Nazi Party 70 years ago. I speak to a historian Mats Deland about what this means

item.title: Radio Sweden 08-08-2011
item.description: Sweden`s economy has weathered the global economic crisis pretty well --
item.itunes:summary: Sweden`s economy has weathered the global economic crisis pretty well --

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-05
item.description: The crisis in the Horn of Africa is getting increasingly worse but the political climate makes it difficult for aid organisations to help. Stockholm stock market dropped more than 3 percent Wednesday, down nearly 18 percent for the year. But considering Sweden’s strong economy what is the reason for this rollercoaster ride? When a priest in southern Sweden came to work one morning part of the church was filled with water, why? Well, someone had stolen parts of the copper roof, and copper theft has become an increasing worry for many of the country’s churches. At the end of today’s programme Dave Russell will be along to present our review of the week gone by.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-04
item.description: Train operator SJ on the defensive as more young passengers come forward to say they too have been kicked off a train The case involving Sweden`s largest ever doping ring has reached an end after a court hearing lasting seven months Sweden is reportedly falling behind its Scandinavian neighbours when it comes to access to psychiatric care Joy for Malmö after a dramatic night of European football Find out more about the Swede shocked to discover that his efforts to build a nuclear reactor in his home was illegal.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-03
item.description: How an 11 year old girl was kicked off the train at night in the middle of nowhere by a ticket inspector, prompting an overnight police search. We examine Sweden`s laws regarding artificial insemination for Bisexual and lesbian couples and speak to a proud mum to be. Despite strict monopoly laws, Are Swedes a nation of gamblers? We meet one woman prepared to go where no space tourist has gone before And are Swedes a nation of worriers when it comes to their children and accidents?

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-08-02
item.description: Online crime is on the rise but police lack the resources needed to patrol online. Those who live in Stockhom might have noticed that even the inner-city busses are decorated with the rainbow flag as Stockholm Pride kicked off on Monday. We take a look at some of the main issues for this year`s festival. Yet another study says there is no link between mobile phones and cancer, this time among children. And, 66 years has passed since Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg was arrested by Soviet troops at the end of World War II but his story continues to fascinate people, and now a new book provides new details about his life and the mystery surrounding his death.

A round-up of the weekend`s sports action including swimming success in Shanghai. And it`s shaping up to be a good year for one of Sweden`s woodsy delicacies, kantareller, or chanterelle mushrooms. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-07-29
item.description: The latest figures are out on the state of the economy - we look at how long Sweden can do well, when the rest of the world is in crisis. A study indicates that if an employer thinks you`re gay, it will affect your chance of getting an interview, at least in some jobs. And as usual on Friday`s we`ll be reviewing the news of the week gone by. Music: Åsa Jinger, `Som en sommarvind`. Presenter Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-07-28
item.description: In the wake of the deadly attacks in Norway, Swedish authorities and police today examine their response times if a similar atrocity happened here.. Boys and young men who sell sex over the internet are asking for help in increasing numbers. And the power of the net has led to the swedish government support international efforts to broaden its use in spreading democracy Also we meet the Swedish coach of the US Women`s football team, Pia Sundhage, who`s no stranger to Bob Dylan.. And the return of a local delicacy in Sweden, long under threat of extinction, the smoked eel....

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-07-27
item.description: The Swedish far-right were mentioned with praise by the Norway terrorist - we talk to a member of that party, the Sweden Democrats, about their views. Sweden is also extending a helping hand to the survivors of the Norway bomb and shooting, we talk to the Red Cross. A serious threat to Sweden`s bees has just been discovered in the south-west of the country. And we take a look at Sweden`s tough alcohol laws, and the chance of them actually being relaxed. Music: Adam Tensta "They wanna know." Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-07-26
item.description: Today`s programme is again dominated by the terrorist attacks a short way over the border in Norway. Some Swedish politicians are reacting by calling for tighter laws on gun ownership. Most of the victims of the attacks were young members of the Norwegian Labour Party. The Swedish young Social Democrats are very close to their Norwegian comrades, and we talked to the Swedish youth leader. Plus we look at the quality of the reporting of this terrorist attack - did Swedish journalists do a good enough job? And we hear about a protest camp that`s currently taking action against a Swedish military test zone in the far north. Music: Til Ungdommen, Helge Engelbrecht/Nordahl Grieg. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou

Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

Also on the agenda, a seminar on asylum policies in the EU. Then we`ll look back at some of the top stories from the week gone by.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-07-06
item.description: We continue with our coverage from the week of heavy politics on the Baltic island of Gotland. Today we’ll be reporting on the speech by Left Party leader Lars Ohly, and a seminar on the law that regulates hiring and firing. Persecuted authors from abroad are being given a special opportunity for temporary asylum. There’s a controversial proposal to limit Sweden’s unique right of public access to nature, even when it’s on someone’s property. Peru’s president says he plans to sue Gothenburg for the return of two thousand year old textiles. But the city’s director of culture tells us they are already in the middle of negotiations.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-07-05
item.description: Sweden`s central bank hikes the key interest rate for the seventh time in the past year. A high-profile trial about an honor killing wraps up - what has wide media coverage of the case meant for Swedish society in terms of integration issues? One university reports troubling sex habits among Swedish youth. Sweden`s big political week in Gotland sees the conservative Moderates take the stage. We stay at Almedalen for a discussion about the new `Swedish film wonder`. Music: "Warning Song" from the soundtrack to the "Girl with the Dragon Tattoo". Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-07-04
item.description: One Swedish journalist has been locked in an Eritrean jail cell for nearly 10 years with no trial. Could a new effort by international lawyers be about to change that? Then, we`ll fill you in on Sweden`s biggest political week, Almedalen, underway now in Gotland. The Greens new spokespeople are first up on the main stage. You`ll find out about the controversy stirring as Swedish hospitals plunk money into building more and more private rooms. And director Ingmar Bergman may have lost his chess game to Death four years ago, but his legacy lives on now during Bergman Week. Music: "When I grow up," First Aid Kit`s cover of Fever Ray`s song. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

And we`ll also be having our usual round up of the highlights of Radio Sweden`s reports from this week.

item.description: Will a labor dispute here in Sweden lead to a breakdown in daily services and have smelly consequences? We`ll hear why one of America`s most powerful trade unions is here in Sweden. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.description: The discovery of a Soviet submarine on the sea bottom off the Swedish coast is raising new questions about the Cold War cat and mouse game in the Baltic. The government strikes a deal with an opposition party on immigration policies, including the right to healthcare for undocumented migrants.. New figures reveal problems in the system that took people off sickness benefits and sent them looking for jobs. Our reporter takes to the roofs of Stockholm to find out how this cold and snowy winter has meant a lot of extra work to keep people on the sidewalks from getting clobbered by snow and ice.

item.description: Today, the 28th February 2011, is the twenty-fifth anniversary of the murder of Swedish Prime Minister Olof Palme. Loved by some, hated by others, his murder is still unsolved. Also in the programme, the continued efforts to evacuate the few Swedes remaining in Libya.

And we`ll have reports on the Music Industry`s Grammy Awards and the Jerring sports achievements award. Music: Håkan Hellström "Trubbel" Presenter: Ulla Engberg
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 2011-01-17
item.description: As the world is watching the developments in Tunisia, we`ll be speaking to one of the Swedish hunters caught up in the unrest. In Sweden, a legal expert claims the Supreme court has put so high demands on children`s evidence in sexual abuse cases that it will become virtually impossible to bring abusers to justice. Swedish EU Commissioner Cecilia Malmström says Sweden needs to do more to fight the risk of cyber attacks And we`ll meet up with Sweden`s and Norway`s biggest chat show host Fredrik Skavlan.

item.description: The forced deportation of Iraqi refugees from Sweden continues despite UN criticism that it’s too dangerous. item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-07-14
item.description: An ex-minister who resigned and was later accused of paying for sex speaks out for the first time today: we hear from the reporter who interviewed him. There is a sharp division within Swedish health bodies over whether gay and bisexual men should be allowed to give blood. And we`ll be hearing more about the love-hate relationship Swedes have with the English language. Music: `The botten is nådd`, Timbuktu.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-07-02
item.description: It’s legal to sell sex in Sweden, but illegal to buy it. So how well has the law against purchasing sexual services worked? Ten years since the Öresund bridge linked Denmark with southern Sweden, now there are calls to build a second span between the two countries. This weekend sees the kick-off of the annual week of intense politics on the island of Gotland, with just over two months to go to the elections. Now it’s proved, having a pet is good for your health.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-07-01
item.description: The Swedish Central bank doubles its key interest rate. But will it head off inflation before it has a chance to start, or just turn the recovery into a new recession? The first of July sees many new laws on the books here in Sweden, the last legislation from the center-right government before this September’s elections. Thursday also marks the end of conscription and the switch-over to an all volunteer army. A new study reveals testing can cut the risk of prostate cancer in half.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-06-25
item.description: Summertime - when it`s finally here Sweden sometimes seems like a different place. Light fills the Scandinavian world - in the north, it`s daylight 24 hours a day, and even here in Stockholm there`s only about six hours of darkness during the height of summer. So today we`re looking at Midsummer, the Swedish celebration always held on a Friday, between the 20th and the 26th of every June. It`s the very highest height of summer; the days are at their longest. It`s the epitome of this short and hastily enjoyed time of year.

The government proposes a solution to the Catch 22 on ID cards. Questions about environmental labelling. Midsummer is coming, and with it the start of a new season of very special Swedish radio programs. Among the hosts we’ll be talking to, former American convict Annika Östberg.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-04-20
item.description: Coming up , the news here in Sweden and our programme dominated again by the fall-out from the Volcanic ash cloud both economically and politically. It`s not only the airlines and travel operators haemoraging money with each new day of closed airspace, diverse, smaller businesses from rose sellers to speciality food importers are struggling too... But every volcanic ash cloud has a silver lining....there are winners as well as losers, for the Scandinavian ferry companies, business is booming as Stranded Swedes on the continent head to the seas... There`s also brighter times ahead for the local economy with the Royal wedding in June expected to bring in more cash than early estimates suggested... And we meet the photo journalist who scooped Sweden`s press picture of the year... Enjoy the programme

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-04-16
item.description: We`ll be concentrating much of the programme on the problems facing air travel in Northern Europe at the moment due to the ash cloud blowing in from Iceland. We`ll be speaking to the people that decide if and when to reopen airspace over Sweden. And to one of Sweden`s leading vulcanologists, who says this eruption is special. And then a bit later on to one of the biggest debates in Sweden over the past 50 years, nuclear power, and the controversial referendum back in 1980.

item.title: 2010-03-28 Konflikt in English on Radio Sweden
item.description: Have you ever felt like somebody is watching you? Had a strange name pop up on Facebook wanting to be your friend? Had someone pay special interest in what you are up to and who you are talking to? Many of us wouldn`t pay that a second thought. But for some refugees and immigrants it could be something much more sinister. It could be the government of their former home country keeping track of what they are up to. In this edition of Konflikt in English we look at espionage in refugee communities here, and its effects for those living with the consequences.

item.description: Sweden takes over EU operations to stop pirates and illegal fishing fleets in the waters off Somalia. political parties banging on the doors of schools to talk to the youngsters in these months of parliamentary election campaigning, a dying woman’s appeal to end her life kindles a renewed debate over euthanasia banned by Swedish law, a Swedish writer and psychiatrist comes out with a new book dedicated to her tail-waging pet and some new Swedish jazz inspired by a world-famous American conductor and a composer.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-03-17
item.description: In today’s program: a critical voice from the small island nation of Malta blasts Swedish refugee policy, Radio Sweden is closing its short and medium wave services, Swedes and foreign visitors discuss providing more international assistance to the rainbow human rights struggle around the world and some more modern jazz created together by a mother and sons - along with other Swedish musicians.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-03-16
item.description: SIPRI`s annual report of global arms trade is rife with unsettling increases. Nearly half of Sweden`s university graduates don`t find jobs in their field within a year of graduation. SR International`s own Amun Abdullahi Mohamed has been awarded the Publicist Club`s Anna Politkovskaja Prize for Freedom of Speech and the Press. Stockholm`s Architecture Museum is exhibiting works by Greta Magnusson Grossman, a designer with a much bigger name abroad than at home.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-03-15
item.description: Six months before the general elections we take a closer look at the incumbent government’s former election promises /// We ask why Swedish teams do so badly on the European stage as the new football season kicks off /// We hear the voice of UIrika Pontén, a Swedish ballad singer who used to work on a totally different field /// And we get to know Sweden’s entry for the Eurovision Song Contest 2010

item.title: Radio Sweden: Konflikt in English 2010-03-14
item.description: Maars, Reaper, Swords, and Predator... The face of war is changing as robots and remote-controlled drones hit the battlefields... and in the future the drones may not be remotely controlled by humans at all. They could soon be making life and death decisions all by themselves. In this week`s Konflikt in English on Radio Sweden, we look at robots and what they will mean for warfare in the future. We speak to one of the world`s leading experts on robot warfare; one of the pioneers in the US robot industry; two witnesses that have gotten used to the sound of drones hovering in the sky; and we`ll pay a visit to Linköping, Sweden`s robot capital.
item.itunes:summary: Maars, Reaper, Swords, and Predator... The face of war is changing as robots and remote-controlled drones hit the battlefields... and in the future the drones may not be remotely controlled by humans at all. They could soon be making life and death decisions all by themselves. In this week`s Konflikt in English on Radio Sweden, we look at robots and what they will mean for warfare in the future. We speak to one of the world`s leading experts on robot warfare; one of the pioneers in the US robot industry; two witnesses that have gotten used to the sound of drones hovering in the sky; and we`ll pay a visit to Linköping, Sweden`s robot capital.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-03-13
item.description: The Swedish artist at the centre of an alleged international murder plot. There were some ruffling of diplomatic feathers, when Sweden`s Prime Minister and Foreign Minister went for a state visit to Moscow.. .. and then on Thursday a major diplomatic upset, when the Swedish parliament decided to recognise the genocide against Armenians and other groups at the end of the Ottoman empire. A Swedish court decides to extradite a former neo-nazi accused of ordering the theft of the infamous Arbeit Macht Frei-sign from Auschwitz. Shipwrecks, several hundred years old, found on the bottom of the Baltic Sea and then Dolph Lundgren, Hollywood action man, joins the Swedish Eurovision fever. Music: Alice Babs "Droppen Dripp och Droppen Drapp" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-03-12
item.description: Turkey calls home its ambassador, and the prime minister cancels a visit to Stockholm, after the Swedish parliament votes to label the deaths of Armenians during World War I as genocide. A substance in breast milk has been used successfully to treat cancer. Growing concerns as more and more Swedes take out loans through text messages. The Swedish finals to the Eurovision Song Contest are this weekend.

Rosanne Cash, daugher of Johnny Cash is visiting Sweden. Music: Anna Bergendahl "This is My Life" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

Human trafficking is a grim part of Stockholm`s underworld, where between 200 to 400 young women work as prostitutes every year.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-03-02
item.description: Swedish scientists discover that bacteria that many have called harmless can actually cause deadly cases of meningitis. The government has a vision that Sweden will become Europe`s top food destination. Races are being held in the central province of Dalarna during the run-up to the 50,000-strong Vasaloppet on Sunday, one of the largest cross-country ski races in the world. Ski fever has even infected Stockholm, with people skiing right in the middle of the city.

item.title: Radio Sweden - Konflikt in English 2010-02-28
item.description: Iraq goes to the polls next week, in what has been called by some observers as a crossroads for the nation. But for whom is it most important? And why? In this week`s Konflikt in English hear about the election through the eyes and fates of four people who have lived through the occupation in the country. Will we see a repeat of the 2005 election, after which the country fell into sectarian conflict? Or will things carry on as usual, or even normalise? We`ll also hear from two potential voters living here in Sweden. Presenter: Kris Boswell

item.description: The fall out from the arctic weather continues .... Sweden`s heavily criticised National Rail Operator SJ blames the government for the catalogue of delays and stoppages on its network. The finger of blame is also pointed by the government at what it calls the "unacceptable" level of danger posed to the public by collapsing roofs And if delays and dangers to public health weren`t enough, Swedes once again face record high electricty bills In other news we examine Sweden`s famed system of income tax

We revisit Sweden`s triumphs and tears during the first week of the Winter Olympics in Vancouver.

item.title: Radio Sweden Konflikt in English 2010-01-14
item.description: An English language edition of Swedish Radio`s foreign affairs magazine Konflikt. Is there such a thing as nice nationalism? Or is it just playing into the hands of the far-right? Find out about Gordon Brown`s Britishness, the French government`s attempts to form a French identity, and the atmosphere here in Sweden, where "Swedishness" has become both an attraction and a worry for lawmakers and the entertainment industry. Presenter Kris Boswell Producer Ivar Ekman

item.title: Radio Sweden 2010-01-30
item.description: The big news this week: A review of this weeks top stories: Dutch luxury car maker Spyker will buy Saab. Champagne corks were popping in Saabs hometown of Trollhättan, but there were also plenty of sceptics. Spyker CEO Victor Muller, hailed as a saviour in Trollhättan, responding to his critics. With over seven months to go to the Swedish elections, the two possible future prime ministers went head to head in debates on TV and the radio. The Award Ceremony of the Swedish equivalent of the Oscars - the Gold Bug. Music: José Gonzalez and the Books "Cello song" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

The big question for many was: to take the vaccine or not? A court has ruled that the National Health Insurance Agency has been discriminating against pregnant women. The opposition protested, but the Swedish government went ahead and said yes to the Nord stream gas pipeline. Sweden`s New National Football Coach for the men`s team. We`ll have a full run down on how people voted as well as expert reaction. It`s not just politics, there`s food and sport as well. We`ll look back on a weekend which saw Sweden`s National football side lose a vital world cup qualifier at home to Denmark and Super Swede`s Robin Söderling`s French Open Tennis adventure came to an end at the final hurdle.... And join us for a taste of Stockholm in Restaurant day..

And what help is there available here? We`ll be finding out.

item.description: he funeral takes place this weekend of a ten year old girl murdered on her way home from football practice, but the decision by SVT to broadcast the burial ceremony live on television has sparked heated debate. In today`s Inside Sweden we meet a somali man who`s set up a Somalian environmental organisation in Sweden to draw attention to green issues in his native country and get somalians interested in nature in Sweden.

The seemingly endless violence in Somalia receives worldwide attention but the environmental degradation of the country including large deforestation and the dumping of nuclear waste receives little coverage. In today`s Inside Sweden we meet a somali man who`s set up a Somalian environmental organisation in Sweden to draw attention to green issues in his native country and get somalians interested in nature in Sweden.
item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 2008-03-21
item.description: Easter is a very special holiday season in Sweden, with many customs going back to the Middle Ages. Today with our host George Wood we`ll be exploring those traditions as well as some modern changes. We`ll learn about the Easter witches who go trick or treating on Holy Thursday and travel -- at least in myth -- to the spooky Blue Mountain, and we`ll visit the open air cultural museum Skansen to find out about Easter food. We also take you to Stockholm`s Sofia Church where there are many celebrations of this very religious festival, including a Rainbow Mass, and on the line to the headquarters of the Swedish weather service, we`ll find out about the arrival of Spring.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2008-02-15
item.description: The mother of a 16 year old girl who died falling from a balcony in Malmö says her daughter was a victim of an so called honour killing and blames social services and school authorities for what happened. After the government pledged money to help provide protection and support to those victims of honour-related oppression, we hear from the President of a women`s Forum who says Swedish authoririties have been poor at spotting the warning signs and preventing honour crimes but matters are improving. Also in the programme, we hear from an organisation which helps immigrant women in need.

And in a country where for every 10,000 inhabitants there is only one store that will sell you aspirin, plans are afoot to break up the pharmacy monopoly.

Should asylum seekers from conflict zones be allowed to cite risks created by the general situation in a country, rather than demonstrating they are personally threatened by violence? We hear some experts.

item.description: We bring you today’s moving stories as well as a story which continues to move Swedes: the terrible tsunami of three years ago. Paintings, drawings and stories. Children from the hardest hit countries remember. Looking ahead: how will you be listening to Radio Sweden in 10 years time? Does shortwave radio have a future?

item.title: Radio Sweden 2007-12-28
item.description: In today`s program, Estonian folk music, choir music and the sounds of Estonian guitar players performing in Stockholm. We take a special look at Swedish-Estonian relations -- today as Nordic neighbors no longer divided by Cold War barriers which lasted for half a century following World War II -- and yesterday centuries ago -- when Estonia was part of the Swedish relm. We`ll also see how Estonians at home and here in Sweden will celebrate Estonia`s 90th anniversary of its independence from Russia with the fall of the Czar.

item.title: Radio Sweden Christmas Special
item.description: In this festive frenzy of a programme, we`ve got the build-up to the big day, excited Christmas kids, disgruntled goats and a bevy of Christmassy Swedes. We talk to a folk law specialist to uncover the origins of Swedish Christmas food or "julbord", and find out why Santa comes to Swedish children in person. Join us as we stroll through the Christmas market in the ancient heart of the Swedish capital. We hear from Stockholm`s mission to the homeless to hear how Swedes are being urged to make some worthwhile Christmas gifts. We also have a special Christmas message from the English group here at Radio Sweden International.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2007-21-12
item.description: Inside Sweden Click and complain - reporting discrimination becomes easier as the Swedish Ombudsman Against Discrimination has relaunched its website. They began with vitually nothing, but today they own a fortune. The Grimaldi family belongs to the richest immigrants in Sweden. We meet “bicycle king” Salvatore Grimaldi.

item.itunes:author: Sveriges Radio

item.title: Radio Sweden 2007-12-20
item.description: Radio Sweden Thursday Despite the ongoing debate over climate change, Swedes do not seem to bother about polluting the air. The number of Swedes flying abroad increases significantly. Swedish police register up to 60 cases of rape every day. With the majority of the perpetrators aged younger than 30, Swedes have begun to wonder whether the younger generation actually knows how to deal with sexuality. A Swedish businessman has launched an unusual school project in South Africa to combat poverty, unwanted pregnancies and AIDS with education, safe sex and self determination.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2007-12-19
item.description: Radio Sweden Wednesday Radio Sweden today covers a European Union slap at Swedish labor unions who boycotted a Latvian construction company working here. Hear about a United Nations report predicting that climate changes will have more of a devasting effect on the developing countries. We`ll also visit an art exhibit at the Estonian Embassy here in Stockholm to discuss the dramatic flight of the artist and other colleagues fleeing to Sweden during WWII.... and hear some Swedish Rock and Roll - played by blind singers and musicians.

item.title: Radio Sweden 2007-12-18
item.description: Radio Sweden Tuesday Foreign Minister Carl Bildt welcomes the outcome of the donation conference for the Palestinian territories held in Paris but urges the international community to help Palestine regain strength. If you still haven’t baked your gingerbread house and you need inspiration, then the architecture museum in Stockholm and its exhibition of gingerbread houses is the place to go. All that jazz! Meet two new Swedish jazz musicians who produced their first album at the age of 60.
